TALK.START.PARA: —The Territories Law Reform Bill is a very important piece of constitutional legislation for this Parliament. The Opposition certainly supports and endorses the broad thrust and the principles of this legislation. However, we do have a number of important reservations that will become apparent during the course of my speech.

PARA.TAB: It is important to recognise that the history of the Indian Ocean territories—that is, Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island—has been very peculiar in the history books or the annals of Australia. The islands are the remnants of nineteenth century colonialism. They have inherited a body of law—Singaporean law—that is still with us today in its application on both Cocos (Keeling) and Christmas islands.

When Australia assumed responsibility for these islands in the 1950s, these laws were in place. It is a shame that nearly 40 years later we are only now addressing these very fundamental legal issues to incorporate the legal regimes of these islands and to bring them into a consistency with, and to have similar standards to, mainland Australia.

To put it in context, it is always important to recognise that the Cocos (Keeling) and Christmas islands are relatively small in both size and population. They are so distant from the Australian mainland that they often get overlooked or forgotten in much of the contemporary discussion about Australia. They certainly are very different when we look at their geography and their particular natural attributes.

The Cocos (Keeling) Islands comprise 27 very beautiful islands but only two of them are populated, whereas Christmas Island is well known largely because of the phosphate mining that has taken place there over many years and which has grown into an important industry.

Approximately 600 people live on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and 1300 people live on Christmas Island. So, in terms of size, they could be compared with average high schools in a suburban location elsewhere in Australia. Often, in degrees of sophistication, educational standards et cetera, they are probably very similar to high schools—and also in terms of the administration. But we have a very complex net of issues that we have to address.

With regard to the ethnic diversity that exists on both islands, it is important to recognise that expatriate Australian public servants constitute a minority of the populations on both islands and perform essential public service-type functions and roles. The majority ethnic groups on the islands are of Malay descent but are from different backgrounds. The people on the Cocos Islands largely went there originally for the exploitation and development of copra by the Clunies-Ross family in a past era. On Christmas Island, largely as a result of phosphate mining, the community that has developed is more recent and of both Malay descent and Chinese-Malay descent.

The community of interest of both of these islands could probably be best aligned to Western Australia, because in more recent years essential services have been provided by various Western Australian agencies, particularly in the areas of health and education. The communities of Cocos and Christmas islands have been linked through air traffic with Port Hedland, Geraldton and Perth. Therefore, a community of interest has built up and has been established with Western Australia.

We also need to recognise that both islands are strategically very important to Australia. They are, in effect, our aircraft carriers in the Indian Ocean. There are no significant defence establishments on the islands. But because of their history in the Second World War and their importance in our regional defence planning, we must always take account of the facilities available there that would naturally be used by both the Australian Navy and the Australian Air Force.

I mentioned earlier that the islands were important because of the number of people on them. Therefore, we need to be interested in job opportunities for the people who live there. We must ask this question about the island, as we do about the rest of Australia: what are the fundamentals of unemployment? In the various departmental briefing notes I have seen on this matter it is recognised that unemployment on Christmas Island is currently running at 22 per cent and that there is the potential in the near future for unemployment on Cocos Island to run to 30 per cent. Such unemployment produces very abnormal social infrastructure requirements that must be addressed.

When we consider this legislation, we need to refer to the second reading speech of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), which contained a number of qualifications with regard to the application of the law. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It should be understood that while this Bill will replace the essentially Singapore based regime with a Western Australian based body of law, this regime will still be subject to modification by Ordinance under the Christmas Island Act and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act. A number of Ordinances are to come into force in conjunction with commencement of this Bill. The most important will deal with interpretation of Western Australian laws in their application to the Territories, and modification of those laws to suit the particular circumstances of the Territories. A further Ordinance will be introduced for Cocos to abolish the Trust under which land is currently held by the Cocos Council, which will enable mainland-style land dealings to take place. The abolition of the Trust in favour of freehold title has the strong support of the Cocos Community.
Additional Ordinances may be required in the future as the consultation process continues and modifications are required to overcome unforeseen problems or situations peculiar to the Territories.
The Minister also said in his second reading speech:

Non-judicial powers and duties under the applied Western Australian laws will be vested in the Commonwealth Minister administering the Christmas Island Act and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act. The Minister will be able to direct that particular powers be vested in other persons or authorities, provided they fall within a range of classes specified in this Bill. The Minister will also be able to delegate powers to such persons or authorities.

It is important to recognise that some 700 Western Australian Acts of Parliament will be transferred in their administration to these islands as a result of this legislation. As the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Ms Fatin) has alluded, a number of them will then be either repealed or have their operation suspended or modified in some way to their general application. This, therefore, raises the complexity of this particular issue.

PARA.TAB: This legislation process has developed and evolved over the last decade as the various Federal governments have sought to move the islands to mainland standards. The Grants Commission was involved in a report on Cocos (Keeling) Islands in 1989. In 1990 the Government developed a memorandum of understanding with Cocos. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs brought down a very important report, Islands in the Sun, on the legal regimes, to which the Government responded in March 1991. So there has been a process that has got the Parliament to the point of addressing this legislation here today.

We must be careful that this legislation does not then become a form of modern-day paternalism and colonialism, having regard particularly to the haste with which it is being pushed through this Parliament. This legislation was introduced in the Senate on 27 May 1992 to avoid the process of introducing it more properly in the House of Representatives where the Minister resides. The legislation should have been subjected to debate in the House of Representatives in the first place. But, in order to meet the Government's program timetable, it was brought in here on 27 May to bypass that process. It is now being put through under guillotine here today in a one-hour debate. It is then to go off, as a result of my actions, to a Senate committee for half a day next Monday for consideration of the implications of this important legislation. If the committee reports after next Monday, the legislation will then be forced under guillotine through the House of Representatives in one day next week.

To anyone dealing with constitutional change, that is a totally unsatisfactory parliamentary process on such an important issue. The process has not been clearly explained or understood on Cocos (Keeling) and Christmas Islands. The time that is being given to this legislation will not correct the problems of inefficiency, particularly with regard to the administration of the islands, or properly recognise the aspirations of the residents—the Australian citizens—who live on Cocos (Keeling) and Christmas Islands.

There has been inadequate consultation with the islanders and the interest groups. The Government and the Department may well argue that they have been talking, but it has been a very one-sided conversation. There has been plenty of paperwork—I have certainly read plenty of it—but there is no established mechanism that properly creates a consultative ideal. There is no joint consultative constitutional committee established with the residents of Cocos (Keeling) and Christmas Islands for the legislation's implementation, as was the case for self-government in the Northern Territory. There is no working party. In fact, I would call for the establishment of a joint working party on the constitutional development issues that will arise from this legislation.

Given that the laws of Western Australia will now apply to these islanders, it is a fact that the residents of Cocos (Keeling) Island and Christmas Island have no representation in the Parliament of Western Australia, where the bulk of their laws will be made. They are part of my electorate—the Northern Territory—for voting purposes here in this Federal Parliament. That, therefore, poses a very important and fundamental constitutional issue.

At the same time, we need to ask: what are the other arms of government doing? We know that the Federal budget for the administration of Cocos (Keeling) and Christmas islands is about $20m per annum. That is a large and significant vote of Federal money for 1,900 islanders in the Indian Ocean. We give something less than a $1m for the administration of Norfolk Island, which has a population approaching nearly 2,000 people and which is largely self-sufficient constitutionally, legally and financially. There are some very important issues to be addressed in the areas of budget for the administration and self-perpetuation of the bureaucracy and various government departments.

We have seen in recent days a program put before the Joint Committee of Public Works. Although no public works or capital projects for Christmas Island or Cocos (Keeling) Islands were announced in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement, a week or two after the statement the Government glibly commits $37m for a five-year program and indicates that it wants to spend $132m over a 10-year period. The Government then sends the program off to the Public Works Committee without having acknowledged it whatsoever in the Prime Minister's statement. Certainly, there has been some serious questioning of the priorities and the construction timetable for $132m of taxpayers' money. I am not saying that capital works do not need to be carried out on either Christmas Island or Cocos (Keeling) Islands, but the way in which the capital works program is being pushed with the same haste as that which is happening here to legislation is important.

We see the creature of the Department of Administrative Services in its usual expansionist power grab putting its tentacles out and now reaching into the Indian Ocean. We all know the inefficiencies of DAS and the way it has operated over the last few years on mainland Australia. Imagine how it is now going to approach that particular issue as it seeks to spend $132m in the Indian Ocean Territories.

I recently paid a visit to Christmas and Cocos (Keeling) Islands, and I particularly thank the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, for making available VIP transport for that trip. Mr Chaney, Mr Lloyd and myself were able to go as a shadow Ministry team to sit, talk to and meet with all of the community organisations and ethnic groups and a large number of people on both islands. The trip certainly related to our portfolios. We were able to take our wives, staff and a member of Dr Hewson's staff, and it was an invaluable trip. I am sure the impressions that Mr Chaney gained with regard to national parks administration and the impressions that Mr Lloyd gained with regard to primary industry, quarantine and resources issues were fundamental in lifting our understanding of local problems.

Coincidentally, we were there at the same time as the Public Works Committee was visiting and appraising the rebuilding and construction program on Christmas Island. I am certainly looking forward to an interim report from the Public Works Committee next week in this Parliament, and it will be very interesting to pick up and reflect on the priorities established.

The sorts of constituency issues that arose were very fundamental and germane to this legislation: housing; housing rentals; housing purchases; land; commercial development; business corporate law support; staff changes; the implication of staff changes in areas such as marine, nursing, administrative services; asbestos replacement programs; education and health services; the application of family law; the rating that will apply to Commonwealth properties; staff transfers to various government departments; quarantine standards; stevedoring; and freight. These issues just serve to highlight much of the cynicism and suspicion about the motives of this legislation and the haste with which it is being foisted through this Parliament. I said in evidence the other day before the Public Works Committee that, to a large extent, the cart was being put before the horse. Certainly, many of the ministerial discretions that will now have to be exercised with regard to finances and legislation in that area are very questionable. Of course, we need to particularly address the issue of duplicate bureaucracies that will be built up.

A number of concerns have been expressed to me by various bodies which I have passed on to the Senate Committee that will look at this issue on Monday. Of particular concern is the legal position of the ownership of land.
The Council's legal rights are based upon a 1984 deed between the Commonwealth and the Council which states:

"To have and to hold unto the Council its successors and assigns in fee simple upon trust for the benefit, advancement and well being of the Cocos Islanders resident in the Territory on land owned by the Council".

"The Council its successors and assigns will not grant demise or otherwise alienate (except by will in favour of members of their own family) the conveyed land or any part thereof without the previous sanction of the Commonwealth".
The Council holds the land currently in trust for the Cocos Islanders.
To set aside this trust requires either:
(a)The agreement of the majority of the persons covered by the Trust.
(b)An Act Of Parliament.
Point (b) is the path the Commonwealth have taken to set aside the trust to transfer the land freehold to the Council.
The majority of the Cocos Islanders wish to be able to purchase the land, and the houses, built upon them on a freehold basis.
However, I believe that the majority of the Cocos Islanders covered by the Trust, do not understand their current legal position under the Trust. Briefly these are:

(a)In 1984 Cocos Islanders were staying in houses built upon land that was transferred by the Commonwealth to the Council under a trust arrangement. At no point were the Cocos Islanders occupying the houses given any legal documentation by the Council as to their rights of occupancy.
(b)Subsequently the Home Island Building Program was to commence, funded 80% by the Commonwealth and 20% by the community. The funding of the 20% by the community was achieved by a combination of:

PARA.TAB: (1)The Co-operative paying rent for those houses occupied by its employees to Council up until June 30, 1990.
(2)The Council receiving direct Social Security benefits and paying only a portion to the persons entitled to and paying only a portion to the persons entitled to the benefits.
(3)After July 1, 1990 occupiers of houses paying rental direct to the Council.

INTERJECT.PARA: Thus the community have paid the community contribution of 20% via the Council to the Commonwealth.
As old houses were demolished and new houses were constructed under the Home Island Building Programme, upon completion of the new houses, the Commonwealth passed title to the houses to the Council.

The community were therefore occupying houses held under trust for them by the Council, paying the 20% contribution (which has been paid), and are still continuing to pay rental to Council which under the Act will obtain freehold title to the land and buildings which they may sell to the Cocos Islanders at a value set by them. This value may or may not reflect the contribution made by the community.
Although Council may have agreed to the change of ownership, I believe that no vote has been taken by the person covered by the Trust, and a majority decision obtained.

I personally believe that the Cocos Islanders are not aware of the full implications of breaking the Trust, and prior to breaking the Trust I do not believe they know the terms that will be offered to them to purchase the land and buildings on a freehold basis.

SUBMISSIONS IN RELATION TO THE PROPOSED TERRITORIES LAW REFORM BILL 1992
1. INTRODUCTION

1.1As the Minister is no doubt aware, Phosphate Resources NL is the company which carries on phosphate mining on Christmas Island. Phosphate Resources NL acquired the rights to carry on that business as a result of the acquisition of a mining lease by tender from the Commonwealth Government pursuant to a Lease Agreement dated 26 September 1990. That lease gives Phosphate Resources NL the right to mine the phosphate reserves situated on Christmas Island for a period of ten years commencing from 26 September 1990, with an option of extension for a further period of ten years.

1.2On 22 September 1988 the then Attorney-General requested that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs conduct an enquiry into the legal regime of Australia's external territories, which of course included the Territory of Christmas Island. The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee and its recommendations were subsequently issued in March 1991. That report, under the heading "Islands in the Sun" made a number of recommendations and was particularly damning of the human rights abuses which had occurred on Christmas Island (refer paragraph 3.6.22). A copy of the 12 recommendations made by the Committee in relation to Christmas Island is annexed to this submission as Annexure "A". It is the submission of Phosphate Resources NL that the Territories Law Reform Bill and its manner of introduction and implementation ignores many of these recommendations.

1.3Phosphate Resources NL refers to its meeting with the Minister on 22 May 1992 at Rockingham. During that visit, Mr Peter Huston, on behalf of Phosphate Resources NL, in conjunction with Mr Lai Ah Hong, who attended on behalf of the Union of Christmas Island Workers, raised a number of concerns in connection with the proposed introduction of the Territories Law Reform Bill 1992 and in particular the undue haste with which the law of Western Australia was being introduced to Christmas Island.
1.4Those concerns which have been repeatedly voiced by Phosphate Resources NL and which were reiterated at our meeting on 22 May 1992 were in summary as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)The undue haste with which the new law is being introduced;
(2)The lack of consultation, education and advice with, of and to the residents of Christmas Island in relation to the proposed new law;
(3)Human rights violations in relation to the introduction of the proposed new law;
(4)Selective and discriminatory enforcement of the laws of Western Australia on Christmas Island;
(5)General legal and constitutional defects or uncertainty in the legislation;
(6)Citizenship issues;
(7)Administration and local government;
(8)Lack of any formal agreement with the Western Australian Government;
(9)Breach of the mining lease between Phosphate Resources NL and the Commonwealth Government;
(10)Additional taxes, charges and expenses;
(11)The Casino.

INTERJECT.PARA: 1.5Thank you for your letter dated 3 June 1992 which refers to some of the issues summarised above. Unfortunately however, the proposals contained in your letter do not alleviate or overcome the substantial concerns and problems associated with the introduction of the proposed new legal regime on Christmas Island which are identified in this submission. Much of the information as set out in your letter of 3 June 1992 is also contained in your second reading speech and in our view fails to recognise the fact that the Territories Law Reform Bill is being introduced without sufficient participation or consultation with, advice to, and education of, the people on Christmas Island.

1.6It should be clearly understood however that Phosphate Resources NL is not opposed to the introduction of Western Australian law to Christmas Island in conjunction with a reform of the existing legal regime. There is no doubt, as identified in the Islands in the Sun Report that the existing system of law needs to be modified and reformed. However, that process of modification and reform needs to be carried out in a refined, phased and planned manner by the selective introduction of Western Australian laws which have been identified as being necessary or appropriate after a process of review, consultation and education. A totally new system of law should not be introduced by the wholesale application of some 700 acts and a whole body of common law without any proper or adequate explanation, review or education.

1.7In summary, it must be recognised that it is unreasonable and indeed impossible to introduce over 90 years of legislature and common law in a nine month period. It certainly is impossible to do so and expect the people of Christmas Island to properly understand those laws.

1.8For the purposes of this submission, it should of course be noted that the shareholders of Phosphate Resources NL comprise in excess of 300 small and large investors, all of whom are residents of Christmas Island and members of the Union of Christmas Island Workers. The views expressed in this submission thus relate not only to the commercial, but also to the social, concerns of the company. Phosphate Resources NL recognises that it has a substantial social responsibility to its shareholders in addition to its business objectives. That responsibility is reflected in the views and submissions expressed herein.
2.THE UNDUE HASTE WITH WHICH THE NEW LAW IS BEING INTRODUCED

2.1The Islands in the Sun Report recommended that the law of Western Australia should be extended to Christmas Island. This recommendation was accompanied by a strongly held view of the House of Representatives Standing Committee that the law needed to be introduced in a manner which recognised the needs of the people of Christmas Island (refer paragraph 3.10.12). Unfortunately and primarily because there has been undue and unnecessary haste in the introduction and application of the Territories Law Reform Bill, there has been no proper or adequate consultation with the people of Christmas Island in relation to that proposed introduction, application and operation of this new body of law.

2.2It was only in late September 1991 that the decision was made for the new law to be introduced. For some reason (which was never discussed with the residents of Christmas Island) it was decided that the law needed to be operative on Christmas Island by 1 July 1992. This provided less than nine months for the residents of Christmas Island, including of course Phosphate Resources NL, to understand the concepts of the proposed new legal regime. Similarly, this only provided a short period of time for the various Commonwealth and State Government departments, agencies and instrumentalities to analyse and review the totality of the laws of Western Australia and to commence work on the best method by which those new laws should be introduced and implemented.

2.3There are in excess of 700 statutes in Western Australia. Despite the best efforts of the Australian Government Solicitor, Attorney-General's Department and all other parties, it is simply an impossible task to review and analyse all or even a major component of these items of legislation to determine their potential impact on Christmas Island and its people within a nine month period. It can take more than nine months for many individual acts to be reviewed and analysed before they are introduced into other States or Territories or to the Commonwealth. It is insensitive to believe that the whole of the legislative and common law regime of Western Australia can be reviewed, analysed, investigated and implemented within a nine month period.

2.4Furthermore, this unreasonable and unnecessary haste means that it has been impossible for proper consideration to be given to the requirement for the implementation of the Western Australian legal regime to be adapted to the special needs of Christmas Island residents (including Phosphate Resources NL) as was emphasised to the House of Representatives Standing Committee. We respectfully refer the Minister to Recommendation 3.10.6 of the Islands in the Sun Report where it was indicated that "the laws needed to be introduced selectively and in line with the culture of the Island". The wholesale introduction and application of the Western Australian law does not involve any adaptation or selective implementation of the law and ignores the needs and rights of the Christmas Island people. Such wholesale introduction is also at odds with the conclusions of the House of Representatives Standing Committee that the Western Australian law should be adopted in a manner which takes account of local practices, history, customs and traditions (refer paragraph 3.10.12).
3.THE LACK OF CONSULTATION, EDUCATION AND ADVICE WITH, OF AND TO THE RESIDENTS OF CHRISTMAS ISLAND IN RELATION TO THE PROPOSED NEW LAW

3.1In paragraph 3.10.14 of The Islands in the Sun Report, the House of Representatives Standing Committee endorsed the view that it was vital for the Christmas Island community to be involved in the reviewing process in the application of the Western Australian law on Christmas Island. Recommendation 6 (paragraph 3.10.18) of the Report stated that it was important to ensure that the application of Western Australian laws was implemented in a way which did not adversely affect the circumstances of Christmas Island or its residents and that a reviewing mechanism must be introduced to avoid that occurrence.

3.2Notwithstanding the statements in your second reading speech as repeated to us in your letter of 3 June 1992 on the education and dissemination of information on the proposed new legal regime, there has in fact been no adequate or proper education of, or consultation with, the people of Christmas Island nor has any participative reviewing process been developed or implemented to study and analyse the laws prior to their application. With respect, dissemination of information via newsletters, radio or television is hardly a satisfactory form of consultation, education or participation, particularly given the nature and content of those newsletters and broadcasts. In addition, the officers of the Australian Government Solicitor have simply had insufficient time to carry out a meaningful analysis of all or most of the statutes of Western Australia.

3.3Furthermore, there has been no analysis whatsoever of the potential impact of the common law of Western Australia on Christmas Island, notwithstanding that the Territories Law Reform Bill states that such common law will apply on Christmas Island from 1 July 1992. Indeed, it is doubtful if many of the people of Christmas Island even know or understand what the common law of Western Australia is or means.

3.4Many, if not most, of the residents of Christmas Island simply have no understanding, training or familiarity with the legislative or common law of Western Australia and have not been properly consulted, advised or educated as to the potential impact of this new legal regime, nor have the residents been able to properly participate in the introduction and the method of implementation of the proposed new legal regime. Many of the residents will not be aware that they have breached the proposed new laws, because they will not be aware of the nature or impact of the law. As you will be aware, ignorance of the law is no defence to a breach of the law.

3.5Whilst you now advise that legal advice will be made available to facilitate the community's awareness of the law, it is imperative that the Christmas Island residents be given access to such legal advice and education prior to the introduction of the law and not after. It is important that the people of Christmas Island be educated as to the operation of the law to ensure that they do not thereby breach the law, rather than imposing the law and then providing legal consultation to provide advice when laws have already been broken, albeit unintentionally.

3.6This lack of education and training in the Australian system as well as the barriers of language, culture and attitude of the people of Christmas Island are acknowledged in the 1991 Strategic Plan prepared by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and the Territories. (Refer Annexure "B" for details of these comments.) That Strategic Plan also acknowledges the need for participation, explanation and equality in the implementation of the new legal system. Unfortunately, these views seem to have been overlooked in the hasty introduction and application of the new legal system from 1 July 1992.

3.7Whilst it is recognised that a significant effort has been devoted to informing the community of the proposed new legal regime, there simply has been insufficient time and resources allocated to informing, educating and advising the people of the potential impact and operation of the new laws. The people of Christmas Island have not been given access to independent legal advice prior to the introduction of the new law, nor have they been given a general opportunity to participate in any analysis or review of the law and its potential application. This lack of available time has been exacerbated by a lack of resources and the inability to marshall and apply those resources. It must be recognised that Christmas Island is a remote community and therefore requires special planning and greater than normal time within which to implement such a substantial and overwhelming change as is contemplated by the introduction of a totally new legal regime. These special considerations do not seem to have been taken into account.

3.8You have mentioned in your letter and in the second reading speech that processes and mechanisms are being developed to facilitate the Island community's awareness of the passage of legislation through Western Australian Parliament. Please advise as to what these processes and mechanisms are. It seems that whatever these processes are, they will certainly not be in existence at the time that it is proposed the new laws will become operative, i.e. by 1 July 1992.

3.9The people of Christmas Island have simply not been advised as to how they can exercise any powers to amend or vary such laws prior to their introduction on Christmas Island. This process needs to be established and explained before the new laws are introduced or become operative, rather than after. In summary, therefore, it is a fundamental requirement that the people of Christmas Island need to have an opportunity to be involved in a review and analysis of laws before they become applicable and not after.
4.HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS IN RELATION TO THE INTRODUCTION OF THE PROPOSED NEW LAW

4.1The Islands in the Sun Report devotes significant attention to actual and potential human rights violations on Christmas Island. Your second reading speech and correspondence acknowledge and refer to these justifiable criticisms. In paragraph 3.6.19 of the Report, reference is made to Human Rights Australia's condemnation of Australia's performance in fulfilling its human rights and international obligations to the residents of Christmas Island. In paragraph 3.6.22 of the Report, the House of Representatives Standing Committee states that it shares these concerns.

4.2However, the introduction of a wholesale new legal regime without adequate review, consultation and education does nothing more than to exacerbate these criticisms and concerns, rather than to overcome or solve such abuses. If the new legal regime is introduced in the manner which is proposed, then this will inevitably result in allegations of further human rights abuse. It is therefore imperative that the people of Christmas Island be properly involved in a review and consultation process prior to the introduction of the law to ensure that their needs, customs, traditions and special circumstances can be properly considered and taken into account before the new legal regime becomes operative and not after.

4.3Mention has already been made by Christmas Island residents of the desirability for United Nations intervention to ensure that the natural justice and other rights of the people of Christmas Island are properly considered at the time of introduction of new laws. The Islands in the Sun Report refers to the fact that Christmas Island might already be a non self-governing territory. The Committee acknowledged that the possibility that Christmas Island is a non self-governing territory is "at the very least arguable" (refer paragraph 3.6.13). The Report also refers to a potential failure by the Commonwealth to deal with Christmas Island in a manner which accords with United Nations treaties or conventions to which Australia is a party (refer paragraph 3.6.22). If the Commonwealth Government proceeds with the introduction of the new legal regime on a wholesale basis, without adequate consultation as is currently proposed, this will inevitably lead to more aggressive action or demands for United Nations review, intervention or supervision.
5.SELECTIVE AND DISCRIMINATORY ENFORCEMENT OF THE LAWS OF WESTERN AUSTRALIA

5.1Directors of Phosphate Resources NL, in their discussions with members of the Administration of Christmas Island and officers of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and the Territories, have raised concerns that if the new legal regime is introduced in the wholesale manner as is proposed, than this will inevitably lead to disputes and arguments, because residents will be in breach of laws which they simply do not understand or simply did not know existed. It has been suggested that this problem will be overcome because the new laws will be enforced and implemented with "discretion and care".

5.2Such a notion of selective or discretionary application of the laws by members of the Administration or the Department constitutes a fundamental breach of the general principle of law that the law should be applied honestly equally and fairly amongst all citizens. Any proposal, formal or informal, express or implied, that the proposed new legal regime will be applied in a selective or discretionary fashion constitutes an anathema to democratic principles of equality, justice and the fundamental rule of law. This again demonstrates the need for proper consultation and education on the potential impact of the laws of Western Australia prior to their introduction and not after.

5.3It needs to be remembered of course that the courts are the ultimate arbiter of what is the law and not Government officers or delegates. It is vital therefore that the application of the law on Christmas Island be fair and even handed in its application and that it be seen to be so.
6.GENERAL LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL DEFECTS OR UNCERTAINTY IN THE LEGISLATION

6.1Based an the legal advice which Phosphate Resources NL has received, it is the view of Phosphate Resources NL that there are a number of defects in the Territories Law Reform Bill in its application to Christmas Island. In brief, these defects include:

PARA.TAB: (1)There is no definition given to the term "Western Australian laws" or "the law of Western Australia".

(2)Section 8A of the Bill seeks to apply the common law of Western Australia, yet there is no way in which the common law of Western Australia can be identified, defined or determined. Thus it is not possible for the legislation to be applied or for the courts to enforce a law, which is uncertain, vague or not properly identified.

(3)Section 8(1) of the Bill seeks to repeal the law in force in the Territory prior to 1 July 1992. There is no definition given to the meaning of the term "law in force in the Territory". Presumably it is intended to include statutory enactments of Singapore and the United Kingdom. This is not made clear. It is questionable as to how the Commonwealth Government of Australia can repeal the application of laws of another sovereign country or foreign jurisdiction.

(4)The Bill seeks to repeal the common law of Christmas Island in existence prior to 1 July 1992 and at the same time states that such repeal does not affect any right, privilege, obligation or liability accrued or incurred under that previously existing common law or anything done or permitted by that law. If however such common law ceases to exist, how will a resident pursue an action or legal right acquired under the common law prior to 1 July 1992.
(5)Lack of formal agreement with the Western Australian Government as referred to in paragraph 9.3 of this submission.

INTERJECT.PARA: 6.2Based on the legal advice which Phosphate Resources NL has received, it is the view of Phosphate Resources NL that the Territories Law Reform Bill and its manner of implementation and application are contrary to the provisions of the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution. This will inevitably lead to litigation over the potential application of Western Australian laws on Christmas Island. It is therefore essential that such constitutional defects be reviewed, analysed and discussed prior to the introduction of the proposed new legal regime, rather than after.

6.3The fact that proper constitutional analysis has not taken place is again demonstrative of the fact that the new law is being introduced with undue haste and without adequate planning, research, consultation or review.
7.CITIZENSHIP ISSUES

7.1There are significant citizenship issues which need to be addressed in relation to the implementation and operation of the proposed new legal regime. Many of the residents of Christmas Island are not citizens of Australia simply because they have wished to maintain their cultural and ethnic links with Asia and with their Asian parents or families. There is thus a need for the proposed new law to consider and deal with these citizenship issues.

7.2The Territories Law Reform Bill makes no reference to the question of citizenship and the manner in which this sensitive issue can be dealt with under the nsw legal regime. This is an issue of vital concern to the people on Christmas Island and needs to be carefully considered and dealt with before the new law is introduced.

7.3It seems that citizenship might become a vital prerequisite for local government/local assembly voting. This issue needs to be considered and resolved before the introduction and application of the Local Government Act or other similar legislation.
8.ADMINISTRATION AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT

8.1The Islands in the Sun Report makes particular mention of the need for the role of the Administrator of Christmas Island to be reviewed (refer Recommendation 13 paragraph 3.12.5). It is noted that the Territories Law Reform Bill contains no reference to this recommendation. Again it is essential, especially as part of the need to remedy any breaches of human rights in the Territory that the role of the Administrator be reviewed and replaced. This should be an essential component of the Law Reform Bill and is not dealt with at any stage in the legislation or the explanatory memorandum.

8.2Similarly, it is recognised in the Islands in the Sun Report that the Christmas Island Assembly will play a vital and central role in the development and implementation of the new legal regime on Christmas Island and the establishment of a new local government body on the Island. In paragraph 3.10.7 of the Report, it is noted that it was emphasised to the House of Representatives Standing Committee that the people of Christmas Island held the majority view of a need for the Christmas Island Assembly to have a "say in respect of the Western Australian laws to be applied" on Christmas Island. In Recommendation 7 (paragraph 3.10.17) of the Report, the Committee acknowledged this concern in its recommendation for the acceleration of the institution and development of a local government body on Christmas Island. It was said that this was important to enable access to the Commonwealth Minister in respect of the new laws to apply on the Island.

8.3The Territories Law Reform Bill makes no provision for either of these essential characteristics of the proposed new legal regime. At this stage it seems that on 1 July 1992 the Western Australian Local Government Act will apply but will not at that time have been amended or modified to ensure that it both applies in a manner which meets the recommendations outlined in the Islands in the Sun Report or the special needs of Christmas Island and its people. The role and powers of the Assembly/Local Government are of vital interest in their potential impact on the operations and business of Phosphate Resources NL. Thus it is important that the company be advised and consulted on this proposed new role of the Assembly prior to its introduction.

8.4Accordingly, it is again essential that the introduction of the new legal regime be delayed until a strategic plan has been developed for the creation and operation of this new local government body. This will again require interaction with the Christmas Island community, including of course Phosphate Resources NL, to ensure that the specific needs and requirements of the people are addressed.
9.LACK OF ANY FORMAL AGREEMENT WITH THE WESTERN AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT

9.1Quite clearly in order of the Western Australian legal regime to apply properly and efficiently on Christmas Island, there is a need for agreement between the Commonwealth and the Western Australia State Government and the various departments, agents and instrumentalities of the Western Australia Government. As at 1 July 1992, no such agreement has been entered into.

9.2It is nonsensical to introduce the new legal regime until such agreement has been finalised. Without such agreement, the law cannot be properly administered or implemented and the residents of Christmas Island, including of course Phosphate Resources NL, cannot properly know or understand the practical manner in which the law will be applied to them.

9.3The Territories Law Reform Bill requires as a major part of its practical application a need for enforcement, prosecution, review or other powers vested in the Commonwealth Minister, under Section 8D(1) to be exercised by Western Australian government departments or authorities under delegation from the Minister pursuant to Section 8D(3). At this stage, there is no framework in place for this delegation process to be implemented. There is little point in introducing legislation until these enforcement and operational procedures have been agreed and finalised between the Commonwealth and the Western Australian Government. Such procedures and agreements may require amendment to the Act or the underlying Western Australian legislation. These issues should be planned, resolved and implemented before the otherwise premature introduction and enactment of the Territories Law Reform Bill.
10.BREACH OF THE MINING LEASE BETWEEN PHOSPHATE RESOURCES NL AND THE COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT

10.1The mining lease between the Commonwealth of Australia and Phosphate Resources NL and others was signed on 26 September 1990. That lease agreement makes no reference to the application of Western Australian laws on Christmas Island, nor was there any express or implied representation or indication given to Phosphate Resources NL of the potential operation of the Western Australian legal regime on Christmas Island at the time the lease agreement was signed.

10.2The implementation of Western Australian laws on Christmas Island will result in Phosphate Resources NL incurring substantial additional taxes, charges and operational expenditure, none of which is referred to in the lease agreement and none of which was referred to or made known to the company at the time of the signing of the lease agreement or the issuing of the tender by the Commonwealth Government. Phosphate Resources NL was thus not given an opportunity to include these new taxes and charges in its planning and budgeting process at the time of entering into the Lease Agreement. The Lease Agreement makes no mention of these additional items of expenditure, taxes and charges.

10.3At this stage, the legislation contemplates that all Western Australian legislation imposing taxes and charges will be applicable on Christmas Island on 1 July 1992, but will be deferred in its operation and effect until 1 January 1993. With respect, such deferral for six months is entirely unsatisfactory. It would have been much more appropriate and responsible for a process of consultation and communication to have taken place between the Commonwealth and Phosphate Resources NL prior to the introduction of the proposed new legal regime and its concomitant taxes, charges and impost rather than after the introduction of that new legal regime.

10.4The proposal by the Commonwealth Government to now implement legislation and common law which will have an unquestionable adverse financial, managerial and operational impact on the company without any consultation or liaison with the company is regarded by Phosphate Resources NL as a breach of the legal and constitutional obligations imposed on the Commonwealth Government. This will inevitably lead to disputation and a substantial claim for damages by Phosphate Resources NL against the Commonwealth.
11.ADDITIONAL TAXES, CHARGES AND EXPENSES

11.1The taxes and charges referred to in paragraph 10 above will also apply to other residents, individuals and businesses on Christmas Island and these parties should also have been given the opportunity to review and discuss the potential operation of these proposed new taxes and charges with the Commonwealth Government prior to their introduction and not after.

11.2Your letter of 3 June 1992 refers to the deferment of various State Government taxes and charges until 1 January 1993. With respect, these taxes and charges need to be reviewed in their totality. There has been no investigation and analysis of the impact of these additional items on expenditure on the Christmas Island community. Again, there has been no participation by the residents of Christmas Island on the impact of these changes. The residents of Christmas Island, including of course Phosphate Resources NL, must be given warning about the effect of these additional items of expenditure, in order that they can be budgeted and planned for.

11.3In the case of Phosphate Resources NL, the impact of payroll tax will of itself create a potential additional annual liability in excess of $200,000.00. Other charges such as Land Tax, Financial Institutions Duty, Stamp Duty and Tobacco Tax need to be planned for. This planning and budgeting process will require at least a two to three year period. These items of legislation should be postponed for at least this period.
12.THE CASINO

12.1It seems that one of the underlying reasons for the haste with which the proposed new legal regime is to be introduced to Christmas Island is fundamentally based on the concern that the Christmas Island Casino will commence operations on 1 July 1992. It was indicated to Phosphate Resources NL that it was essential that the Western Australian legal regime be in operation prior to the Casino commencing operations.

12.2Phosphate Resources NL supports the Casino proposal and does not seek to detract from this project in any way. Nevertheless, the need for the introduction of any new legal regime on Christmas Island should, with respect, be determined by the needs and requirements of Phosphate Resources NL and the Island communities as a whole and not on the basis of the potential operations of the Casino.

12.3In any event, due to litigation and disputation between the Casino owners and the builders of the Casino, it is now unlikely that the construction of the Casino will be finalised prior to 1 January 1993. Phosphate Resources NL understands that, since the commencement of such litigation work has not yet recommenced on the Casino site. Whilst Phosphate Resources NL is confident that the Casino project will unquestionably proceed to completion, such delays mean that the commencement of operations of the Casino will consequently be deferred until well after 1 January 1993. Therefore, this apparent driving force for application of the new legal regime by 1 July 1992 is no longer apposite. There is thus no reason why the introduction of the new legal regime could not be postponed for at least 6—12 months.

12.4In any event, it is possible under the ordinance and Commonwealth legislative system which is already in existence for adequate laws to be enacted governing the conduct of operations of the Casino on an interim basis until the proposed new legal regime can be the subject of proper analysis, advice, consultation and education.
13.THE METHOD OF INTRODUCTION AND FUNDAMENTAL BASIS OF THE TERRITORIES LAW REFORM BILL

13.1Mention has been made in paragraph 3 of this submission for the need for Christmas Island residents to be involved in the legislative review process, in order that they can be aware of new items of legislation. If the introduction of the Territories Law Reform Bill is to be used as an example, then there is significant cause for concern. Despite requests to the government by Phosphate Resources NL for a copy of the Bill in final or in draft, plus the explanatory memorandum and other explanatory information, such documents were never provided. Copies of these draft documents were finally obtained from the Opposition in late May 1992. A copy of the legislation as finally introduced to the Senate was also finally obtained (again from the Opposition) in early June 1992. As you can appreciate, this has only provided a very short period of time for this legislation to be reviewed and commented upon by the company and its advisers.

13.2In addition, Phosphate Resources NL has not been provided with and apparently cannot be provided with the ordinances which are to be passed as part of the Bill to modify, defer or amend the operation of Western Australian legislation in accordance with the Commonwealth Government's statements to that effect. Apparently drafting of some of these ordinances has not as yet been finalised. Please advise as to when these items of legislation can be made available.

13.3At our meeting of 22 May 1992, Phosphate Resources NL raised the question as to why it was necessary to impose the whole of the legislation and common law of Western Australia and then to work backwards to delete those items which the Minister deigns to be inappropriate. It would seem a far more sensible and logical approach for the Commonwealth to adopt and apply on Christmas Island those items of Western Australian legislation (after necessary consultation, review and amendment) as are necessary or appropriate to the needs and objectives on Christmas Island. This would allow any important items of legislation such as the Criminal Code or Family Law Act to be reviewed as a priority and then applied immediately. The Minister indicated that she had raised this very same question and had received advice from the Attorney General's Department, that it was not legally possible to adopt this approach. The Minister indicated that she would again seek confirmation of, and the reasons behind, this advice from the Attorney-General's Department.

13.4With respect, there seems no legal reason why this alternate and, in the view of Phosphate Resources NL, more sensible approach could not be adopted. Could you please advise whether the Attorney-General's Department has as yet responded to the Minister's request for further advice on this issue. If the Attorney-General's Department has not as yet responded, could the Minister please advise as to when a response could be expected.

13.5The Minister's letter of 3 June 1992 also refers to the grouping of Western Australian laws into various categories and annexes to that letter a list of those items of legislation. It is apparent from a review of those lists that many items of legislation (List A2 comprising approximately 140 Acts) apply immediately, but have not yet been fully analysed in detail as to their potential impact on Christmas Island or to businesses or residents on Christmas Island, including Phosphate Resources NL. List B identified 47 Acts which will apply immediately, but which may require modification or further assessment. List C identifies only 115 Acts which are to be suspended until 1 January 1993. Of those Acts which have been assessed and which are being modified, there has been no process of consultation, participation or liaison with Phosphate Resources NL as to those proposed modifications. As you can no doubt appreciate, the failure to have Phosphate Resources NL involved in that process does not give the company confidence that its views, or indeed the views of other residents, will be taken into account in the future, even if a review process is eventually established.

13.6It should also be noted that impact statements on legislation which have been prepared are not in reality statements on the actual impact of legislation on Christmas Island, but rather constitute a general statement or summary on the operation of the statute. It should also be noted that the annexure to the Minister's letter of 3 June 1992 refers to 354 Acts (List A1) which are said to have no significant effect. Yet some of these Acts will affect Phosphate Resources NL and the people of Christmas Island, such as the Petroleum Act and the Dairy Industry Act or if they have no effect, such as the East Perth Cemeteries Act and many others, then why does this legislation need to apply to Christmas Island at all?
14.CONCLUSIONS

14.1It is therefore the submission of Phosphate Resources NL that the proposed new legal regime is being introduced with unreasonable haste resulting in inadequate planning, consultation and investigation. In addition, it is the view of Phosphate Resources NL that the residents of Christmas Island have not been properly consulted, advised or educated in relation to the potential operation and effect of the new legal regime.

14.2It is also the view of Phosphate Resources NL that the manner of introduction of the new legal regime ignores many of the views and recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee Islands in the Sun Report. Undoubtedly, this has occurred because of the lack of time and therefore a lack of sufficient resources (notwithstanding the best efforts of all of the people involved) being allocated to this very difficult and complex, but nevertheless, vital project.

14.3In the Government's own response (refer Annexure "C") to the recommendations in the Islands in the Sun Report, it is acknowledged that a consultation and education process is important (page 6). It is also acknowledged that a mechanism must be developed to facilitate the island community's awareness of the passage of new legislation through Parliament and to assist in the communication and explanation of the effects of such legislation. Yet, none of these recognised issues are dealt with in the Territories Law Reform Bill or the supporting Commonwealth or State Government administrative machinery.

14.4Your letter of 3 June 1992 and your second reading speech also refer to assistance by Western Australian Government Departments and agencies. Yet, as at the date of this Report, Phosphate Resources NL has not received any advice or proposals from these departments or agencies as to how they might apply or operate Western Australian laws on Christmas Island. In any event, such proposals are at this stage likely to be preliminary and superficial, given the limited time for visits to the island and the conduct of the necessary study and investigation by such agencies and departments.

14.5Phosphate Resources NL is aware that similar concerns to those set out in this submission have been expressed by other community and business groups on Christmas Island, including the Union of Christmas Island Workers, the Assembly and the Christmas Island Chamber of Commerce. The fundamental thrust of those concerns has been the unreasonable haste and lack of consultation and participation in the content and manner of introduction of the proposed new legal regime.

14.6In summary therefore, it is the submission of Phosphate Resources NL that it is essential for the Territories Law Reform Bill to be postponed in its enactment by at least a further prior of 12 months until the various issues raised in this submission have been the subject of further investigation and planning.
Yours faithfully
PHOSPHATE RESOURCES NL

I do not believe that any Senate committee or any parliamentary consideration, in a one-hour debate today and a three-hour committee session on Monday, will be able to properly address all of the issues that have been raised, particularly the lack of understanding of the implications of the new regime and its consequent administration; the land tenure changes on the Cocos Islands, which could result in future property sales to people outside the local Cocos-Malay community; the preoccupation and expectation of the 10-year rebuilding program; and the participation of persons other than Australian citizens in local government elections. By the application of Western Australian law, the local elections will apply that franchise more generally. We know that there are fundamental reasons why that happens differently throughout Australia and other areas, but its application in an external territory needs to be fundamentally addressed.

PARA.TAB: The issue of citizenship implies reciprocal obligations. We need to be assured that those residents of both Cocos and Christmas islands who have not taken out Australian citizenship and who now gain voting rights under the application of this law really do have an understanding of their reciprocal rights, obligations and responsibilities. The fact that no formal agreements have been concluded between the Federal and Western Australian governments gives me cause for concern.

I have two letters: one from Prime Minister Hawke to Dr Lawrence, the Premier of Western Australia, and another in response from the Acting Premier, Mr Ian Taylor, to Mr Hawke, dated September and October 1991 respectively. I seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hon Dr Carmen Lawrence, MLA
Premier
Parliament House
Harvest Terrace
PERTH WA 6000
My dear Premier

I am writing to inform you of proposals to reform the legal regimes and associated administration in Australia's Indian Ocean Territories of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island. I am also seeking your agreement in principle for the Western Australia Government to assist the Commonwealth in implementing these reforms.

Reviews conducted by the Commonwealth Grants Commission for the Cocos (Keeling) Islands in 1989 and by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in 1991 found that the legal regimes of the Indian Ocean Territories are now seriously out of date and unnecessarily complex to administer. Both bodies recommended replacement of the present legal regimes with a body of law based on that of the geographically nearest State administration, Western Australia. I am informed that the Committee held discussions with representatives of your Government about these matters.

The Government has decided to accept the recommendations and to apply the laws of Western Australia, as amended from time to time, and all Commonwealth laws, as the laws of the Indian Ocean Territories. It is proposed that the Western Australian based legal regime will be applied as Commonwealth law, under amendments to the Commonwealth's Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act 1955 and Christmas Island Act 1958. It is planned that the new regime will come into force from 1 July 1992.

The responsibility for administration of Western Australian based laws and assistance measures will continue to rest with the Commonwealth. However, the Commonwealth Government believes that it would be desirable for your Government to administer the legal regimes of the Territories, and some Commonwealth programs, on behalf of the Commonwealth.

Accordingly, I seek your agreement to senior officials opening discussions on how best to advance these proposals. The Commonwealth contact is Ms Cathy Santamaria, First Assistant Secretary, Corporate Management and Territories, Department of the Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories (06-2741555). I would be grateful if you could nominate an officer in your Department as a point of contact.

There are a number of other issues which would need to be settled between our Governments. These matters could also be discussed by senior officials if and when your Government agrees in principle to my Government's proposal.
I look forward to receiving your response and, I trust, your in principle support for the measures I have proposed.
Yours sincerely
R J L Hawke
