TALK.START.PARA: —The question, `What is the current Western Australian perspective with regard to these changes?' needs to be asked very carefully. I do not believe that there is any acknowledgment from Western Australia—there are certainly no formal agreements. I think that there would be apprehension on the part of the Western Australian Public Service Commission in this regard at this particular time, especially with regard to the modification of Western Australian laws that is still to occur, the degree of community consultation and the community expectations that are being raised for local government responsibilities.

PARA.TAB: There are concerns echoing through the local communities in the Cocos and Christmas Islands of a Western Australian takeover by way of the application of Western Australian State charges and taxes. I note that the Minister for the Arts and Territories, Ms Fatin, put out a press release the other day saying, `Okay, I will put the taxes and charges off for a few months'. She is not putting the legislation off, but she is putting the taxes and charges off for a few more months. There is a degree of inconsistency in what is going on.

The fourth point is that Western Australia has not yet agreed to any complementary legislation or entered into any service delivery arrangements or agreements. Those agreements are not yet concluded. It has been said that there have been discussions, but those agreements are not in place. Western Australian agencies have not yet concluded their discussions on island about the operating arrangements. There is a vagueness about the delegation of powers that will apply in a week's time on 1 July to hundreds of Western Australian Acts.

We certainly need to call into question the qualifications of the Administrators of both the Cocos Islands and Christmas Island to apply 700 Western Australian laws. I am not denigrating either of the current Administrators. One is from a union background, the other comes from a Labor background in this Parliament. But the qualifications and legal expertise needed to administer the legal implications are fundamental and important. It needs to be asked, `Will the Administrators be able to cope with the responsibilities that will be imposed on the Minister and, through him or her, the Administrators of both islands?'.

There are also a number of thorny issues running around both of these Indian Ocean Territories that are linked and very indicative of the poor administration. I will throw out a very humorous one—the purchase of an $800,000 rescue boat on Cocos Island. There was a RAAF crash in the island lagoon last year and no-one could get to the plane to service it quickly, so someone went out and bought a new rescue boat, but it cannot get up the damned lagoon. It cost $800,000. What have they named this boat? They have named it the R J Hawke, without any consultation with the local community. The Malays of Cocos Island are thoroughly offended. Normally, a vessel of this nature would go through a process of naming in accordance with the Malay culture. The imams and everybody else have been insulted by this.

Then there is the casino on Christmas Island. In a question to Senator Collins earlier this week I highlighted the fact that the Indonesian developers of a $50m casino on Christmas Island have suddenly stopped work. The Minister assured me that there were no consequential financial problems on the island. I spoke to the President of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday and he said that the subcontractors had not been paid and, in turn, therefore, a number of suppliers and other people have major questions about payment.

With regard to this casino, the Department of Employment, Education and Training has been engaging in an extensive education and training program in which hundreds of young people participate. That program now looks as if it will fall over. What will be the development for these young people?How will the club licensing that is necessary for gaming clubs on Christmas Island and the recreational club on Cocos Island continue? How will they be administered? How will the clubs service tourists? The issue has to come under the licensing laws of Western Australia.

The corporate change in the structure of the trading cooperative on Cocos Island is also fundamental. It will drastically change the equity of the shareholding participants on that island.The Government is entering into a funny deal with regard to the purchase of Oceania House—the Clunies-Ross historical home—on Cocos Island. It is doing a trade-off with North Keeling Island, a national park, and the local council taking over this important heritage property—a swap of a million dollar property when it already has North Keeling Island. Suddenly it is doing a sleight of the hand which will involve extensive costs in the future.

What about small business support on either of the islands—the underpinning of enterprise development? It seems to me that the Department was looking at the casino as being the fundamentally important linchpin. I question whether the haste to get this legislation in place is in order to accommodate a gaming regulation control mechanism for the operation of that multimillion dollar casino. This legislation is not aimed at tourists from Australia, it is aimed at Chinese, Indonesian and Malay millionaire gamblers who will need to put $50,000 on the table before they walk into the casino on any weekend. I believe that the haste with which this legislation is now being foisted on this Parliament is predicated on a deal between the Government and the Indonesian casino developers. To ensure that there is no funny business going on there, I accept that there needs to be a good control mechanism for the casino, but it now appears that the project is in jeopardy and could well fall over. So why the haste? Questions do need to be asked. Is it because of ministerial incompetence? Is it because the Department snowed either the Minister or the Government with the pressures that have just been built up? The issues that were addressed in the House of Representatives report, Islands in the Sun, are fundamental. They are very important.

The process that is now being put in place is one that can only lead to disaster if it is not done properly. If the arrangements with the Western Australian Government are not all out on the table, it could well be another WA Inc. under another guise. I believe that will be a fundamental issue. Unless the Western Australia Government is prepared to come out and say, `Yes, we back this. We are in bed with this deal 100 per cent. Here are all the contracts, here are all the agreements', we will probably be fighting in Estimates committees and other places of this Parliament for the next 10 years. There is certainly apprehension on the islands.

One needs also to ask: is there a financial cover-up because of the commitment of the $132m to a capital works project by the Government? It this legislation needed to prop that up, or is it introduced because of the growth aspirations of various government departments?

In conclusion, I refer to the final clauses of this Bill, relating to the dealings with Norfolk Island, which only highlight the inconsistency of the legislation. We are well aware that the Government has been locked in an argument with Norfolk Island for some time about the incorporation of Australian residents on the island into an Australian electorate for voting purposes. The Government came to an agreement; it made a deal. The Government settled all of that a month ago but it could not get it into this legislation. All the Government has done in this Bill is tidy up the pay packets of the members of the Legislative Assembly on Norfolk Island. The Government can foist 700 Western Australian Acts of Parliament onto 1,900 people in the Indian Ocean but it cannot tidy up the major Norfolk Island arrangements which were surprisingly so important. The Government set the political agenda by trying to get the people of Norfolk Island into a Labor-held Canberra seat. That fell apart and became embarrassing because the Government did not win—the Norfolk Islanders had a better view of the issue and won at the end of the day. The Government did not bring Norfolk Island into this legislation because it did not want to go through a legislative process. Yet it can attempt to snow the Parliament on Cocos and Christmas Islands.

I sincerely hope that when the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs sits on Monday and looks at the submissions it has already received—perhaps some more will come in over the weekend, because I will be inviting the residents of Cocos Island and Christmas Island to fax in additional comments—it will say to the Government, `Hey, your pace is too fast'. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it almost anachronistic to be talking about Territories these days—nevertheless, we are. We have to ensure that residents of Territories have a right to the same principles of law as the rest of us. The Territories Law Reform Bill is unusual. It proposes to replace the legal systems which apply in the Territories located off Western Australia. Commonwealth and Western Australian law would replace the existing legal systems commencing from 1 July this year.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tambling has given a thorough overview of the scope of the legislation. I intend to be brief. I have not had the benefit of a visit to the Territories so I will have to rely on the evidence presented to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs and a reading of the legislation.

There are separate provisions in the Bill with respect to the legal systems of Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, as well as an unrelated amendment concerning the devolution of power to set the remuneration of members of the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly. As has been said, this Bill arose from a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled Islands in the Sun. That Committee examined the legal regimes which exist in Australia's external territories. The report pointed out that the current situation is totally unacceptable in some regards. For example, on Christmas Island there are laws from Singapore and the United Kingdom which include some archaic penalties, such as flogging.

The matters in this legislation are complex and will be fully investigated by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which is conducting an inquiry into this Bill on Monday. The Democrats will be represented on that Committee by Senator Spindler. We have received some representations that, at least in respect of Christmas Island, the adoption of the Western Australian legal system should be delayed because the residents are not yet prepared for, nor cognisant of, the laws which will apply to them from either 1 July 1992 or 1 January 1993. As always with legal changes, there are commercial matters which get caught up and which will be affected if this legislation is agreed to—changes which affect the phosphate mining operation which is the major business undertaking on the island.

I think we should also remember that there are a lot of other matters which were raised in the Islands in the Sun report that are not dealt with in this legislation. For example, the Territories of Ashmore and Cartier Islands are to be incorporated into the Northern Territory, and the rather ticklish issue of the Federal voting rights of residents of Norfolk Island has not been satisfactorily resolved. However, many of the controversial questions will be dealt with by the Committee on Monday. Senator Tambling paints an alarming picture of some of them. I was glad to hear that it was not another deal with the Democrats, but with the Indonesian Government this time. The Democrats will be supporting the second reading of this Bill and we will reserve our position on the other matters until all the evidence is collected on Monday.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this place I represent Tasmania, which is probably the place in Australia which is farthest away from the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, and one might wonder why I would want to stand here and say a few things about the Territories Law Reform Bill. Firstly, obviously I have a responsibility not only as a senator to represent Tasmania but as a senator to represent the whole of Australia, including the people of Cocos (Keeling) Islands, who overwhelmingly voted to be part of Australia.

PARA.TAB: This is a Bill which purports to give a legislative response to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled Islands in the Sun: The Legal Regimes of Australia's External Territories and the Jervis Bay Territory. I have listened carefully to what Senator Tambling and Senator Kernot have said. I have looked at the second reading speech and, as far as is possible, the explanatory memorandum. It did not occur to me until this morning that this Bill should be of quite major significance to all members of the Senate.

Senator Tambling has described the fact that hundreds and hundreds of pieces of Australian legislation—that is, Federal legislation and Western Australian legislation—will be imposed upon the peoples of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. The question that I want to raise is whether those people have been properly and adequately consulted. Senator Tambling is shaking his head, indicating that they have not been properly and adequately consulted.

Senator Tambling, of course, has particular interests as a senator for the Northern Territory and has the capability, which others do not, of going to Cocos and Christmas islands and studying the situation there. He has reported to us this morning. I am concerned that there is a far greater need for the rest of us in this chamber to study the implications of this measure. I note in the second reading speech that the only court which is specifically to have jurisdiction in Cocos and Christmas islands from 1 July 1992 is the Family Court of Western Australia exercising jurisdiction under the Family Law Act 1975.

I am glad to see that Senator Tate is the Minister in the chamber. I think that on Senator Tate and his colleagues will fall the responsibility of deciding whether the Family Law Act in Australia is appropriate to impose upon the peoples of Cocos and Christmas islands.

A large number of concerns are being expressed within Australia about not only the administration of the Family Law Act but also the basis upon which the Family Law Act in Australia has been founded, which causes feelings of injustice amongst hundreds and thousands of people in Australia. Such tragedy has been caused as a result of recourse by certain parties to the provisions of the Family Law Act when those parties simply wish to opt out of their responsibilities. These are the sorts of considerations which I believe the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Ms Fatin) and the Government must again consider. Indeed, they must consider whether the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island agree with that. To properly consider it, they must have further consultations with them.

I do not know—and I note that Senator Tambling, in his speech on the second reading, indicated that he did not really know—whether there have been full, adequate and complete consultations with Western Australia. We were told in the Minister's second reading speech that hundreds and hundreds of Western Australian laws will apply to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island after 1 July 1992. The second reading speech said that it is expected that some 350 Western Australian laws could be applied in full from 1 July 1992 without adverse impact. It also said that approximately another 140 laws would have a noticeable impact but that the on-island changes required could be readily accommodated from 1 July 1992.

I have not seen those laws. It is important that the Senate and, more particularly, the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island see what those laws are in Western Australia. It is important for the Minister at the table, Senator Tate, to see what they are. With this piece of legislation, the Government is imposing not only the beneficial but also the adverse aspects of certain Federal and Western Australian laws on the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island. I do not think we should do that lightly. We are doing it lightly if we propose to carry this measure through this chamber under the guillotine.

The Government is not giving true freedom of speech and expression to the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island because it has not adequately consulted them. And the Government is not giving us our rights of expression because it has agreed to the guillotine. It has limited debate on this measure, as it has limited the debate on a number of other measures. Under those circumstances, I believe it is essential that this matter be deferred until those prerequisites occur—that is, proper consultation with the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island after they have been provided with the detailed information that they need for the consideration of the implications that this measure will have for them.

I agree that it is important that this matter be referred to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee. But it sat for only three hours on Monday. What can one do in three hours? I believe that under those circumstances the Government should indicate, if not now then on Monday, that this matter has been deferred until the Budget sittings.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Before calling the Minister, I note that other senators had been listed to speak on this Bill, but they have withdrawn. I call Senator Tate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the second reading of the Territories Law Reform Bill 1992. It is most important that the report of the House of Representatives Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled Islands in the Sun: The Legal Regimes of Australia's External Territories and the Jervis Bay Territory be given parliamentary recognition and that the implementation of many of the recommendations of that Committee be undertaken by this Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia.

PARA.TAB: These Territories have had a certain dependent relationship which is now to be transformed into one more closely akin to that which obtains in other parts of the Commonwealth. I understand that up to this point the legal regime governing residents in those Territories—or at least in the Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands Territories—has been based on imperial law and Singapore law. Quite clearly, it is inappropriate that that continue to be the case. One needs to have a legal regime which is more closely aligned to that of the Commonwealth of Australia. In relation to that, it is said that Western Australian law should be adopted because it is the case that there is—

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be the Northern Territory. That is their representative in this place.

—As I understand it, the fact is that Western Australia is the jurisdiction with which most islanders have close links. In fact, not only are shipping and air services originating in Perth, but also Western Australia is the main source of the island's food, medical and other supplies.
—Why are they in the Northern Territory for voting in the Federal Parliament?

—Most importantly, I understand that Western Australia is now the home of many Cocos and Christmas islanders, and more people of Cocos and Christmas island origin have chosen to live in Western Australia than remain on the islands. All I am doing is defending the point that Western Australian law is the most appropriate legal regime to be now put in place in order to govern the residents of those islands and their various activities.

PARA.TAB: As to the question of consultation, in relation to Cocos, for example, after the act of self-determination undertaken by the United Nations where the people voted overwhelmingly for integration with Australia, I am advised that proposed changes were discussed in extensive consultations with Cocos Malay community leaders. This was all encapsulated in a memorandum of understanding signed by the then Prime Minister and the Cocos community leaders in March 1991.

So far as Christmas Island is concerned, I understand that once again a great deal of effort has been put into discussions with the community in order to inform it not only about its beneficial entitlements, but also about its obligations and the impacts of the new legal arrangements which might be adverse—to use Senator Harradine's terminology—in respect of those living in that community. Because of the need to ensure that the community is not submerged in inappropriate law, there are categories of laws—some categories of Western Australian law which will apply immediately, others which will not be applied and others which will be put into a sort of limbo category and deferred for further consideration. That has been done to ensure that the laws of Western Australia are modified where necessary in order to deal with the special circumstances of the community of Christmas Island.

Senator Harradine asked about the family law provisions. I understand and I am advised that, in relation to Christmas Island, the Malay community leaders have concurred with the application of the Australian Family Law Act to the island community. If that is the case, then that is a form of consultation which has to be given proper weight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have they been made aware of the ramifications?

—I suppose they are able to inform themselves of those matters and I hope their concurrence was based on a fair appreciation of all the ramifications, as Senator Harradine says, of adopting that regime. This is a complex matter and I understand it is being referred to the Senate Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on Monday, when witnesses from both island communities—
—Only Christmas.

—Witnesses from Christmas Island only will be present. They will have an opportunity to put their point of view and, in any case, I am quite sure they will be ably represented by Senator Tambling and others who will be putting a case on behalf of perhaps some members of the community, although I do not think even Senator Tambling would claim to be able to speak on behalf of them all. It will be a most important committee meeting on Monday. On that basis the Senate chamber ought to give this Bill a second reading, allow the matter to be considered in the Committee and then determine what to do on the basis of the Committee's report to this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Pursuant to the order of the Senate agreed to on 3 June 1992, the Territories Law Reform Bill 1992 stands referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for consideration and report by the first sitting day occurring after the Bill is considered on a Friday reserved for committee meetings.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will be supporting the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992, the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992 and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1992 which are now before the Senate. I take this opportunity not only to note our reservations about these Bills and some aspects of them which are inadequate, but more particularly to move amendments on behalf of the Opposition to all three Bills.

PARA.TAB: The present Government, after nine tired years of centralism, is continuing to let down the people of Australia in the whole education area—in schools, in technical and further education and in universities. In a number of areas we have now reached a crisis point as a result of the bureaucratic interference of this Government and the suppression of initiatives that can locally be made to meet the needs of Australians in schools, in TAFE and in universities. We in the Opposition are fed up with the failures of the Labor Government in education. I am convinced that the only way ahead now is for the Government to lose office at the coming Federal election and for the imaginative and positive policies set out in the coalition's Fightback package to be given a chance to bring remedies for our schools, for TAFE and for universities.

The States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992 is, for the most part, in the usual format for this time of the year in giving supplementation of moneys. In particular, it gives an extra $15m in capital grants for non-government schools in 1992. This is hopelessly inadequate—$15m extra when in fact there should be a doubling of the moneys available to meet the capital needs of the non-government schools of Australia. The coalition is committed to a doubling of capital grants, that is, $81m, not the measly $15m that this Government has come up with in this Bill.

The whole policy of the Labor Party for the last nine years has been increasingly to put screws upon middle Australian families—a whole 25 per cent of Australian families who want to enrol their children in schools of their choice, disciplined non-government schools in which they have confidence. But this Government has prevented such schools being built. So there is a huge set of waiting lists around Australia for such schools. All I can say is that the Liberal and National parties will immediately remove those restrictions placed by the Labor Party on the formation of new non-government schools so that families can exercise their choice, as is their right and as ought to be the freedom in Australia.

Let me give one example only from my own State of South Australia. Trinity School in Gawler has recently been established. It has the objective of excellence in education, good resources and also a very big commitment from its teachers. I know well the principal of the school, Mr Michael Hewitson, whom I have known since a teenager. Lo and behold, this school is full. Not only is it full, but there is also a waiting list of 4,000 students in the northern suburbs of Adelaide who want to go to this new school. This waiting list has been relieved by a recent extension of the school to another campus, but it is typical of the frustration of many Australian families at the moment, and this is inadequate provision by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. At this point I move the amendment to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill which has been circulated. I move:

PARA.TAB: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate deplores the Government's continued mismanagement of higher education and, in particular, the Senate deplores the Government's:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)determination to maintain a flawed system of funding for higher education;
(b)failure to provide a satisfactory regulatory framework for the development of higher education;
(c)failure to provide adequate opportunities for young people to lift their level of knowledge and skills and thereby to address a significant contributing factor to youth unemployment;
(d)pursuit of policy which prevents some 50 000 qualified Australian students from gaining places in tertiary institutions; and
(e)failure to address the serious inequities of current arrangements".

I conclude my speech, knowing that this Government is sensitive to the continuing criticism, not only by the Liberal and National parties, but also by our colleagues in this matter, the Democrats. I am sure Senator Sowada in her speech will reinforce the view that we all have in the Senate, by a clear majority, that the Labor Government is failing Australia in every area of education—in schools, in TAFE and in higher education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I rise to discuss the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1992, the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992 and the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992. These three cognate Bills are adjustments to funding levels which occur on a fairly regular basis and as such they give us an opportunity to have a rave about the state of education in Australia. Many of the increases outlined in the Bill were flagged as part of the Government's One Nation package. The Australian Democrats will not be opposing these Bills. I have also indicated to Senator Teague that we will be supporting his second reading amendment in respect of universities and TAFE, but not for schools.

PARA.TAB: The current education debate is tightly focused on the issue of competency based training and the future role of TAFE, despite glaring deficiencies in our school, higher education and university systems, which also need to be addressed. It is an appropriate time to evaluate these reforms that have been implemented over the last five years and to investigate future directions. What emerges from this process is the need for a blueprint that clearly outlines a future education and training system for Australia, given that the responsibility of TAFE is now up in the air. A more flexible and expanded education system is required to meet the needs of a changing work force and to deal with the effects of award restructuring. The introduction of new technology in the workplace has rendered many unskilled and low skilled jobs obsolete. Our work force and employers must face the need for better training and multiskilling in the face of these enormous changes. This is also important in the light of soaring school retention rates, the consequent high levels of unmet demand in further education and record levels of youth unemployment.

The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill 1992 before the Senate today amends the Higher Education Funding Act 1988. Introduced by the Hon. John Dawkins, the Act marks a radical change in the higher education sector, with reforms the pace and extent of which are unprecedented. Clause 26 of this Bill alters the maximum level for capital grants for higher education institutions over 1992-94, and includes funding to address enrolment pressures.

This Bill also reflects the funding transfer for the John Curtin School of Medical Research from the Department of Employment, Education and Training to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. The recent Senate Standing Committee report into the John Curtin School examined the arguments behind this funding transfer and the notion of university autonomy. Although the Committee concluded that the Minister had not overstepped his brief, the minority report supported by the Australian Democrats denounces this funding change. The responsibility of funding the school should not rest with the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. Despite legal advice which suggests the Minister may have acted ultra vires of the ANU Act, the Government still seeks to pursue this senseless measure. It would be fair to say that universities are still recovering from the effect of the Dawkins reforms. The abolition of the binary divide and amalgamations saw institutions consolidated from 70 to 46 in number, with many of these campuses spread far and wide in geographical terms.

While the potential administrative savings have been attractive, in many cases amalgamations have not been happy ones. For example, in New South Wales the long running dispute between Armidale and Northern Rivers campuses has absorbed much energy from academics and students alike. Thousands of dollars have been wasted as academics from far-flung parts of the State have attempted to meet for regular council meetings. Some amalgamations have made sense, but the Democrats have opposed those ridiculous amalgamations, such as the one I have just outlined. In the case of the University of New England, we have called on the New South Wales Minister for Education to disamalgamate the two campuses post-haste.

The huge growth of student numbers has also seen the proliferation of new campuses around Australia. This is to be welcomed. However, it has also brought with it a debate about the role of universities, as these new campuses have sought to adopt a more entrepreneurial focus to their curriculum. Many of these newer institutions see themselves as providers of education in disciplines which fill a need for graduates in a particular field. Many of the older institutions, designed along the traditional Oxbridge model, have felt threatened by these developments as they have sought to protect their structures, courses and research agendas from the real or perceived threat to their jealously guarded independence. Indeed, I believe it is this essential conflict of style which lay at the heart of the University of New England amalgamation problems.

There is a role for both types of institutions in Australia today. Students are demanding curricula relevant to their needs and their job aspirations. On the other hand, universities are coming to grips with the role they must play in the national economic scene. Higher education cannot be isolated from these developments whilst retaining the traditional role it has played as social commentator, the source of new ideas and the repository of the nation's intellectual wealth.

Increasingly, our educational future will be characterised by advances in technology. The announcement in Western Australia last week that video universities are on the way is one example. The open learning program is now in place and should be encouraged as a means of increasing access to education for traditionally disadvantaged groups, including rural students, part time and mature aged students, especially women in the home caring for children and people with disabilities.

We may even reach a stage in 25 years time when the traditional lecture, which forms the backbone of teaching at institutions, actually becomes obsolete. However, there is a danger in regarding open learning as a solution to the problem of unmet demand. Enrolment trends from open learning programs already record minimal interest from school leavers attempting entry into universities or TAFE. Through distance education and electronic innovations, I believe we are on the verge of a whole new method of learning. This will in the long term radically alter the nature of participation in education delivery.

Open learning also has an important role to play in developing links with other nations. It has great potential as an export service and to strengthen our ties with Asia, one of the strongest importers of education services. Strengthening our links internationally will contribute to our international competitiveness, as well as the quality of our teaching and research. However, we must proceed cautiously to ensure that the best and most effective services and technologies are used. Institutions will still need adequate capital resources. For example, libraries must not be allowed to decline in range or quality.

This debate about the role of universities has again been brought into sharp focus by the current discussions regarding TAFE as the national training provider and its role in delivering post-secondary education. While enrolments at universities have soared over the last few years, interest in TAFE courses has declined from 22 per cent to 12 per cent over the last 8 years, despite increased participation in higher education in schools. This needs investigation, as does the perceived lower status of TAFE in the eyes of the community. Despite this, it is estimated that over 100,000 students missed out on TAFE places this year.

Secondary school retention rates continue to climb and are expected to reach 80 per cent by 1994. The Finn review into post-compulsory education sets new targets for participation and they are to be supported. According to Finn, by 2001, 95 per cent of all 19-year-olds should have completed or be participating in year 12 or a TAFE or training equivalent. This is supported by the Australian Democrats. The Finn recommendations would result in a 55 per cent increase in TAFE places over the decade and estimates from the Ramsay Committee into TAFE indicate that as much as $5 billion to $6 billion is required to meet these recommendations.

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Beazley, claimed in his second reading speech that the Commonwealth was `offering to take full funding responsibility for the development of a new and expanded system of vocational training'. Over the past few weeks we have seen much huffing and puffing from the Government and the States over whose responsibility the TAFE sector really is. Instead of developing a much needed strategy for resolving what amounts to a dispute, the Government has reacted with bluffs, threats and ultimatums. There has been much debate, but little action. To that extent the Australian Democrats will be moving an amendment to paragraph (c) of Senator Teague's second reading amendment on the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill to include, after the word `institutions', the words `without the consent and cooperation of the States'.

It is vitally important, if we are to have a nationally coordinated TAFE sector, that the States be consulted and given some say as to how many of the pressing issues are to be resolved. Clearly that is not happening at the moment. The combination of high levels of unmet demand and record youth unemployment make the development of a clear strategy for TAFE's future imperative. The Australian Democrats believe that TAFE should have a national focus, but threats by the Government to establish a parallel system of vocational training are senseless. We must have a commitment to the creation of a system that is based on cooperation and consultation between the Commonwealth and the States.

I commend the idea of establishing a national training board. It would play a key role in overseeing TAFE while correcting the anomalies that currently exist: different fees, up-front charges and course standards. This idea concurs with the recommendations contained in the Carmichael report. The report, which proposes a new entry level training system for Australia, identifies TAFE as the major provider of advanced vocational training in a network of senior secondary colleges, skills centres and public and private providers of on-the-job and off-the-job training.

Carmichael offers an exciting long term strategy for training in this country with the implementation of competency based training and assessment. However, issues such as youth wage levels and the extent of competency based training need resolution. The Australian Democrats await with interest the youth job summit proposed by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and likewise his proposals about a youth wage. Our concern is that youth wages may fall to unacceptably low levels resulting in the creation of two youth underclasses: those without jobs and those with jobs on below-the-poverty-line wage levels. A fall in the real level of youth incomes must not be allowed to happen.

Clearly a national training strategy is needed if young people are to take their place in the work force as productive employees with a range of skills and able to face a changing workplace. At this stage TAFE, in its currently fragmented form of State based education, is simply not equipped for that role. The issue of credit transfer and recognition of prior learning across State boundaries must be resolved. Funding must be massively increased and the role in this process of continuing education, or adult education as it is sometimes known, must be established and recognised and folded into this dynamic process.

The implications for universities of competency based training are unclear. A university education requires more than delivering curricula from key competencies. The Government must be careful that, when it sets the education agenda, it is not simply asking universities to become an extension of the TAFE sector.

The States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992 provides for an injection of an additional $15m for capital grants to non-government schools in 1992, as announced in the One Nation statement in February this year. Commonwealth funding for non-government schools has increased steadily since the late 1970s, as have enrolments in this area. We do not oppose this funding increase, but I reiterate the support of the Democrats for the government schools sector. We recognise that many parents choose to send their children to non-government schools, and it is their choice to seek the sort of education that those schools offer.

However, Government funding priorities must be with the government sector. Many government schools are underfunded, understaffed, and plagued with poor student-staff ratios, leaky buildings and poor resources. The Government needs to recognise that, as school retention rates increase, additional stresses will be placed on the Budget from government and non-government schools in the long term. Provisions for growth in outlays must be made here as well as in post-secondary education.

In conclusion, four years after the implementation of the Dawkins-led reforms into Australia's higher education system, we have reached a crisis point. As Senator Teague has already outlined, we are faced with enormous levels of unmet demand both in TAFE and at universities that the Government seems unable to resolve. The Government has failed to provide a clear blueprint for its future goals of TAFE.

This debate has been clouded with threats and counterthreats and no clear ideas on the issues of substance. As I said earlier, the Democrats await with interest the sorts of proposals that the Government will obviously be bringing forward over the next couple of months to resolve some of these issues. It is absolutely critical that the current impasse on TAFE is resolved quickly so that TAFE is in a position to deliver the sort of work force that Australia needs to take it into the twenty-first century. I commend these Bills to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today before the Senate are the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill, which have been joined in cognate debate and which all relate to additional funding for various sectors of the higher education system. We currently have a situation where our education system is in crisis. Our higher education institutions are left overcrowded and underfunded. Our schools are crying out for capital works. The vocational education system is straining to meet the enormous demands with limited facilities and 200,000 young people who wish to upgrade their knowledge and skills at either university or TAFE are unable to gain a place at these institutions, even though they are qualified to do so.

PARA.TAB: The Government expects the education sector to pick up the slack from the economic disaster that it has created through the recession we had to have by hiding in post-secondary education the vast numbers of young people who would otherwise be out looking for work. Our young people know that there are too few jobs out there. Instead, they stay at school longer, enter more training courses or go on to tertiary education. Higher retention rates are necessary and should be encouraged, but not as a way of hiding the plight of our jobless young people. Of course, the Government expects the education sector to pick up the forgotten people of its economic disaster; it does not provide the funding that is needed to do so. The result is a demoralised education sector.

These Bills represent a belated funding attempt and go a small way towards what is needed. I turn first to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill. The sole purpose of this Bill is to provide an additional $15m in capital funding for non-government schools. This amount would be welcomed by the non-government schools. However, it is a pittance compared with what they need and compared with the fact that under the Fightback policies of the coalition capital funding to non-government schools will be doubled to an amount of $162m.

I have recently addressed meetings in Gosford and Lismore of up to 800 people regarding the urgent need for capital funding in these areas. I am well aware of the problems facing other non-government schools. Catholic schools on the central coast of New South Wales need an additional $19m. Catholic schools on the far north coast of New South Wales need an additional $39m. If parents want private education for their children, governments should not stand in their way; indeed, they should positively assist.

All the research shows that the most effective schools are those where the teachers and parents work in close partnership. Non-government schools are an essential component of Australian schooling. Twenty-eight per cent of all school pupils attend non-government schools and this is growing by one percentage point per year. The vast majority of children in non-government schools, contrary to popular belief, are from families in the low to middle income range. Non-government schools express not only the right of parents to choose schooling which reflects their values but also the willingness of parents to commit their own resources to schooling on a large scale which make savings to the taxpayer of $1.6 billion a year possible. Government funds are therefore able to be concentrated on government schools.

The requirements for infrastructure have increased substantially because of higher retention rates and changing curriculum requirements. The real annual value of Commonwealth capital grants to non-government schools has declined by almost 30 per cent over the last 10 years of this Labor Government when increased student numbers are taken into account. The coalition believes that the community interest in a viable and high quality non-government school sector is not being adequately expressed in the current government capital works program. Accordingly, the incoming coalition government will double the annual size of capital grants in the program to non-government schools to a level of $162m per year. The increased payments under this program will commence in the 1993-94 year. The level of grant still required for the substantial contribution to capital development from parents and communities supporting non-government schools will, of course, still be there. However, the current burden will be greatly alleviated with the increase in funding that we are proposing under Fightback.

The States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill is the next Bill in this package. It is intended to appropriate funds for TAFE in accordance with the November statement on the economy and employment and to provide supplementary grants for 1992. It is interesting at this point to contrast the Government's TAFE policy with that of the coalition. The Government is struggling to find a TAFE policy. It has proposed to take on the funding of TAFE, yet no-one—not even the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—appears to know whether this will occur.

During the Estimates committee hearings I questioned DEET about the costs and staffing involved in developing the Federal Government's new TAFE proposals launched by the Prime Minister a few Sundays ago. The answer was that it had no resources at all. It turned out that this proposal to create a separate TAFE system was just off the top of the Prime Minister's head.
Senator Collins—He just wants one that actually works, Senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —What? Having parallel TAFE systems? So if we have a TAFE in Maitland, where do the students go? Do they go to the Federal TAFE college in Maitland, or do they go to the State TAFE college in Maitland? What is the difference between the two sets of systems that the Prime Minister was proposing on that Sunday morning? The reality is that the Prime Minister got up and had breakfast one morning and had a bright idea. He then went on Sunday television and proposed it. That is what happened.It was just nonsense. Senator Collins knows it was nonsense. The whole of Australia knows it was nonsense. The TAFE sector was outraged by it because it realised what nonsense it was. The Prime Minister is backtracking on this matter, and so he should. Seeing it was such an outrageous and silly policy, I am surprised that the Minister is even commenting on it.
—It's been a poor relation for too long, Senator Tierney.

—Okay. Let us take that point—being a poor relation for too long. Let us look at the levels of funding for TAFE throughout this decade. While the former Minister for Education was concentrating on wrecking the higher education system by his so-called national unified system—something that is better located in the old eastern Europe, certainly not in a system of autonomous universities—and by amalgamation, he totally neglected TAFE. He did not put any extra funding into it at all. The levels of funding for TAFE throughout this decade have stayed fairly stagnant. The Minister has been in government for nine years. Why has his Government not done something before now? If it is the correct policy to have training levels up now, why was it not the correct policy over the nine years of his Government? If we have levels of training in this country of 23 per cent, but Japan, the United States and Germany have much higher levels, why did this Government not move funding up to that level? Why has the Prime Minister just belatedly discovered this? It is because this Government is running out of ideas; the Prime Minister keeps ricocheting across one idea after the other.
—You're going to cut its throat.

—I think the Australian electorate will do that; we will not have to do anything. Let us go back to the matter of the TAFE sector. If we turn to what the Fightback! document says on our future policy and on the levels of skills in this country, we realise that it is a key aspect of international competitiveness. As I have just mentioned, we are lagging very badly behind our major competitors. We need to increase dramatically the very low levels of training in this area if we are to become an internationally competitive economy.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at some of the overseas rates to underline the points I have made. The participation rate in the post-secondary sector in West Germany is 65 per cent for 18- to 19-year-old males; United States, 58 per cent; Japan, 50 per cent; and Australia, 30 per cent. As the OECD states, much remains to be done to improve the skill of our work force. In Japan more than 80 per cent of firms provide some formal training for the work force. In Australia that figure is 24 per cent. Clearly, much reform is needed.

To this end the Liberal and National parties believe that it is essential to move towards a national reporting of standards of attainment based on nationally accepted and objective forms of assessment for the key competencies required for success in the workplace, particularly language, communication and numeracy skills, extending to scientific and technological understanding of students.

Unlike the Government, there is nothing conditional in our approach. We have accepted the targets for growth in TAFE as outline in the Finn report and we will, in government, work with and not against the States and Territories to ensure greater freedom for TAFE institutions to respond to the need of local industries and communities. This policy contrasts vividly with the policy of the Labor Government to date. For this reason, the Opposition welcomes the Australian Democrats' amendment that we have a more cooperative arrangement.

While TAFE is generally the responsibility of the States, the Federal Government should ensure that a high level of skill in the work force is achieved for the national interest. The Labor Government has never adopted a comprehensive strategy to this end. The money appropriated under this Bill for TAFE, although welcome, is sadly, yet typically, a case of too little too late. This contrasts with the coalition, which recognises the key role of TAFE and which, to ensure that TAFE is adequately supported, has undertaken in the Fightback program to increase funding by $75m a year above the current level of commitment, or $450m, to fund growth in TAFE over the remaining years of this decade.

Finally, I move to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill. This Bill gives effect to the decision announced in the November statement on education and employment and the One Nation statement. It provides the usual supplementation, inadequate funding for additional student intake for the 1992-94 triennium and even more inadequate additional funding for higher education capital works. This is a pathetic attempt by the Government to address the many problems in the higher education sector that it has created.

Problems of unmet demand and overcrowding are largely the result of rigidities imposed by the Government's regulatory and funding framework for higher education. Institutions are limited in their admissions by bureaucratically determined quotas, their access to capital for development is unduly restricted, student charges are determined by the government, course profiles require government approval and there are serious rigidities in employment conditions for staff. All of these factors prevent institutions from responding adequately to demand. Under Fightback there will be sufficient deregulation of the higher education sector so that demand can be met.

Also under Fightback the government will not be attempting to intervene in the autonomy of a university as the Government has done in the ANU. SPEECH.PARA: In addition, the Bill provides for a variation in the funds available under the Act to reflect the Government's decision to transfer funding responsibility for the John Curtin School of Medical Research from the Department of Employment, Education and Training to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services.

PARA.TAB: This Government's attempts to administer the higher education sector have become a farce, as the situation at the John Curtin School of Medical Research illustrates. The three Bills before the Senate today will not be opposed by the Opposition. DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (TRAFFIC IN NARCOTIC DRUGS AND PSYCHOTROPIC SUBSTANCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 18 June, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, I was in the process of putting to the Senate three areas of concern that the Opposition had in relation to the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Amendment Bill 1992. I had just touched upon the third of those concerns which related to proposed new section 8A which reproduces article 3.3 of the UN Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. It provides that, if a particular knowledge, intent or purpose is an element of an offence against the Act, that knowledge, intent or purpose may be inferred from objective factual circumstances. Proposed new subsection (2) provides that this `is not intended to exclude or limit any other way of proving knowledge, intent or purpose as an element of an offence for the purposes of a prosecution'.

PARA.TAB: Our concern is that the provision of this new section may be contrary to a series of High Court decisions to the effect that there is always a presumption that mens rea is required before a person can be found guilty of a serious criminal offence. Under the test proposed in section 8A, the prosecution would not need to prove that the accused knew that his or her conduct was unlawful. The prosecution would only need to prove that the accused ought to have known that the conduct was unlawful. It introduces an objective test for establishing the accused's state of mind.

In the other place, my colleague the shadow Attorney-General referred in his speech on the second reading to the High Court decision in the 1988 case of Pereira, in which it was held that the necessary mental element could be inferred from the circumstances but only with three qualifications: firstly, the question remains one of actual knowledge; secondly, the question is that of the actual knowledge of the accused; and, thirdly, where knowledge is inferred from the circumstances surrounding the commission of the alleged offence, knowledge must be the only rational inference available. The coalition is concerned that these qualifications do not appear in proposed section 8A. The impression may therefore be given that the Parliament has decided to displace the application of Pereira.

Also, in the July 1990 report of the review of Commonwealth criminal law, it was recommended that the minimum fault element for a criminal offence should be recklessness. The Opposition takes the view that the requisite mental element should at least be recklessness. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General, Mr Duncan, argued in the other place that proposed section 8A does not offend against existing principles of liability. A court must be satisfied as to actual knowledge or intent on the part of the defendant. As was made clear in the case of Pereira, such knowledge or intention may be inferred from proven objective circumstances. He went on to say that he entirely accepted the considerations set out in Pereira to be observed in making use of such evidence and he had no doubt that a court, in construing proposed section 8A(1), would apply the test as set out in that case. The coalition does not believe that the matter is as clear as Mr Duncan claims.

I therefore foreshadow that the Opposition will be opposing clause 4A at the committee stage, as we did in the other place. Apart from the concerns that I have mentioned, the coalition supports the Bill, as we do all measures against drug trafficking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President—
—You are not going to give Vinnicombe another going over are you, Noel?

—No, this is a different area. I will be brief. I did not hear what Senator Hill said, but no doubt he was reflecting the concerns that I have. The Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Amendment Bill 1992 aims to amend the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Act 1990 and to further implement the 1988 United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. While the 1990 Act puts in place the Federal legislative framework to enable ratification of the 1988 convention, the 1992 Bill is intended to apply Federal legislation to the commission of State and Territory offences and place Australia in a position to ratify the convention.

PARA.TAB: Australia became a signatory to the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs in 1961. This was later amended by the Protocol Amending the Single Convention in 1972, and the Convention on Psychotropic Substances in 1971. The Psychotropic Substances Act 1976 gives effect to Australia's obligations under the psychotropic substances convention by regulating movement on psychotropic substances. As Senator Hill has said, the coalition supports this legislation, as it supports any endeavours in the war against drugs, particularly at an international level. It is the level of international movement of and dealings in drugs that impinges very greatly on drug activity in Australia.

The purpose of this legislation is to set in place the final stage of the legislative framework to meet the obligations under the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. Australia can now proceed to the ratification of the convention. As I said earlier, the Bill fills in the gaps between State and Territory legislation.

There are a few matters that are of consequence to me. The first is that we are introducing this legislation and dealing with it prior to the States and Territories completing their complementary legislative programs. It is not clear to me which States have not fulfilled their obligations, to the extent that they are obligations, and the reasons for the delays. It is least clear to me to what extent there has been unanimity among, and support by, the States for the necessary legislation.

The second matter is that a serious crime under State legislation is an indictable offence carrying a minimum penalty of 12 months imprisonment. There are many offences that carry that penalty. I wonder, as does the coalition, whether that minimum threshold is too low for the purposes of triggering an offence under this Act and whether it ought to be higher—perhaps at least five years—given that this legislation will provide penalties of up to 20 years in gaol.

I thought I heard Senator Hill discussing my third concern; that is, the proof of knowledge, which has changed. It has moved from a position where a reasonable person may have known an offence was being committed to one where an objective examination of the facts would show that somebody ought to have known that an offence was being committed. In other words, a person can be involved in an offence without knowing it, and then we have this draconian legislation.

I am always concerned, with legislation of this nature, that we suspend the normal standards, measures and tests of law because we believe that the crime is so serious that it deserves different attention—whether it be taxation matters, drug matters or white collar crime matters. The test should not change because of a perceived social attitude towards a particular offence, or because politicians and parliamentarians believe that there is some advantage for themselves or that they are, for the moment, reflecting the contemporary view of the community. It is incumbent upon this Parliament to ensure that the minimum tests and criteria are applied. With those qualifications, I join with Senator Hill in supporting the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Amendment Bill 1992. The purpose of this Bill is to fill in the remaining gaps in State and Territory legislation so that Australia can meet its obligations under the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances and, accordingly, proceed to ratify the convention. Ratification of this convention is in accordance with the Government's ongoing commitment to the international fight against illicit drug trafficking and abuse. The Australian Democrats strongly support the measures taken in that fight. We believe it is a critical one. Accordingly, we support this Bill.

PARA.TAB: The Bill is only intended to be an interim measure until all States and Territories have their own conforming legislation. Its provisions will come into force only upon the commencement of the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Act 1990, the principal Act, which itself is to commence on a date to be fixed by proclamation.

Fears have been raised that the level of proof will be changed by clause 4A. The Democrats will not be supporting the opposition to this clause. I am aware that the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) raised this matter in the other place and demonstrated his concern that it offended existing principles of criminal liability as set out in the 1988 decision in Pereira v. the Director of Public Prosecutions.

The Democrats sought independent legal advice and were told that the presence of the words `may be', which precede the definition of the level of proof, would ensure that the common law is not substantively changed from its present position. On that basis, we will not be supporting the Opposition in opposing clause 4A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to unnecessarily prolong the debate. The Government is also satisfied on the legal advice it has received that clause 4A does not have the effect that the Opposition is concerned about. Therefore, we will not be accepting Senator Hill's opposition to the clause. I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clauses 1 to 4—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are opposed to this clause for the reasons that I have outlined earlier.

PARA.TAB: Clause agreed to.
