DEBATE.TITLE: STATES AND NORTHERN TERRITORY GRANTS (RURAL ADJUSTMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Amendment Bill 1992 gives effect to changes made to the rural adjustment scheme—the RAS, as it is commonly known—through an agreement between the Commonwealth and the States. Under section 27 of the Act, these amendments can be introduced prior to an amendment of legislation to allow much faster assistance for farmers who are in dire financial straits.

PARA.TAB: The rural adjustment scheme has become an elastic bandaid, a means by which the Government can hide its successive failures. Unfortunately, the bandaid has now failed and the rural adjustment scheme really is in need of major surgery if it is to address the problems that will confront agriculture in the next five to 10 years. We do not need another bandaid added to the already overburdened rural adjustment scheme, which is trying to cope with the problems in rural Australia.

Testament to the failure of the rural adjustment scheme is the fact that, of the $10m set aside this financial year to assist farmers to gain the unemployment benefit through the modification of the Job Search allowance, only $200,000 has been expended at this stage. This Government cannot even spend the allocated money on a very specific, targeted assistance project. Why not? Farmers are also asking why not. It is because of poor policy making.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), along with the now fallen Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Richardson, promised on 29 October last year that 2,000 desperate farmers would receive assistance through the Government's reformed Job Search allowance. At the end of April, the number of farmers who were granted Job Search under the modified assets test arrangement totalled 101. Honourable senators will remember that in October last year 2,000 farmers were going to receive this targeted assistance.

After considering the criteria for eligibility, the question is not why so few farmers took up the offer but why so many farmers did not meet such unrealistic and unbelievable requirements. The Job Search allowance does need modification if this targeted assistance is to work and be directed to those very deserving farmers in desperate straits right now.

The rural adjustment scheme is broken down into three components: part A, the interest subsidy component; part B, carry-on finance; and part C, household support and money to adjust out of farming. In order to be eligible for the Government's so-called farmer dole, the applicant must have not further borrowing capacity and must be considered viable in the long term. I am not sure how a farmer would meet both those criteria. If a farmer is to be viable in the long term, he or she is ineligible for the interest subsidy and forfeits any chance of accessing the unemployment benefit. Who then qualifies for the amended Job Search allowance? All available evidence suggests that the benefit will be granted only in quite exceptional circumstances. I believe that the fact that 101 farmers are receiving this assistance is testimony to that assertion.

Let us suppose for a moment that the Government's amended Job Search allowance did assist 2,000 farmers instead of the paltry 101 farmers who are receiving it now. Less than 4 per cent of farmers qualify for the unemployment benefit in the worst year on record for farm incomes and in the worst drought in many parts of the country since records have been kept. It is not hard to deduce from such figures that the Government's assistance program has failed completely. It has failed so many desperate farmers.

I put this failure down to the complete misunderstanding—perhaps ignorance—of this Labor Government. It does not understand the Australian farm sector, and I believe that it does not want to understand it. If it did, this problem would have been addressed prior to Christmas last year. Had those in government listened to this side of the House and taken on board our proposals, this situation could have been averted.

Amendments within this Bill also provide special assistance for crop planting. This assistance has been made available since March this year under part B of the scheme. This assistance is in the form of a 75 per cent interest subsidy on growers' commercial crop planting loans. It is certainly long overdue. Under the terms of the agreement with the States, farmers must be profitable in the long term but be unable to obtain sufficient commercial carry-on finance to undertake normal cropping programs.

The figures to date show that only 160 out of an estimated 40,000 cereal and grain farmers across Australia have applied for the subsidies to help with winter wheat plantings due to the stringent requirements. Many of them have been through the process already. They have been in to see their bankers and rural adjustment authorities. In many cases, even the rural adjustment authorities are saying, `Look, you are better off going in and dealing with your bank. There is so much red tape, I do not think you will qualify. You are really wasting your time and effort and that of your accountants in putting these figures together'.

These figures confirm what we are saying about this scheme. Of 160 applicants, 67 have been approved, 29 have been rejected and 64 are still pending. In fact, the disregard of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for the problems forced on the rural sector was illustrated in his February economic statement when he allocated almost twice as much money to Western Australian sewage treatment as to the crop planting assistance program this year.

We are talking about an export industry which has the capacity to generate $2 billion to $3 billion worth of export income and create countless jobs right across Australia—not just on the farms, but on the wharves where the wheat is loaded, the railways which cart the wheat into the ports and for the truck drivers who bring it in from the farms. It is a great creator of jobs, yet so little of this assistance is flowing to the wheat and cereal growers of Australia.

The coalition's message is quite clear: in times of financial crisis, welfare payments cannot be extended to farming communities through unemployment benefits. Generally, the farmer and his spouse are actively employed on the property from daybreak to dusk, regardless of whether they receive any income. It is, therefore, not practical to offer the Job Search allowance as a means of assistance.

The need for fast track household support reform is, therefore, crucial if farming families are to keep food on the table and if the rural infrastructure is to survive this very desperate period. A coalition government would allow farmers to access the same benefits as every other Australian. The coalition recognises that there is a role for rural adjustment in Australia in order to assist the Australian agricultural sector in overcoming problems unique to it. We recognise the need for rural adjustment; there will probably always be a need for it.

There are lots of other problems that I think the Government must look at. It certainly must look at encouraging farmers to better manage their situations prior to drought. One of the reasons why we have a rural adjustment scheme in place is that there is a lack of programs—programs which the coalition had in place to encourage farmers to put money aside in good times to see their way through the bad times and, more particularly, through the droughts. In many cases, the Government has taken such measures away. It is something that we must look at more closely and the Government must look at it because it obviously has the power of the Treasury bench.

There is another aspect of this whole question of rural adjustment that I hope the Minister will look at. Rural adjustment has been added to, yet some of the problems that are still inherent in rural Australia are problems that rural adjustment cannot cover adequately. These include income equalisation deposits and the 100 per cent write-offs for drought mitigation measures for the storage of fodder, for increased water storage capacity and for the reticulation of water around farms in order to avoid many of the disasters that we have seen in the current drought.

In contrast to the Government, the coalition does have an understanding of the rural sector. It can solve the great many problems facing rural Australia today. We would be in there restoring farm profitability through the implementation of a comprehensive tax reform and economic package, the like of which this country has never seen. We would have an effective industrial relations policy which would give reward for effort, which every Australian wants. We would encourage people to work. The more people worked and the harder they worked, the more they would earn to take home to their families. We would do that rather than continue the restrictive work practices that Government members have encouraged and nurtured for years and years.

In conclusion, I ask the Minister to look at the real problems confronting so many farming families right across Australia. We may have seen a return to better prices for some commodities, but the problem that many farm families face today is one of walking off their farms with nothing to show for a lifetime's work. I believe it is up to each and every one of us in this chamber and the House of Representatives to look at how better to target the Job Search allowance and the whole rural adjustment scheme in order to assist those who are in genuine need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Amendment Bill 1992 at a time of absolute crisis for rural Australia. The national broadacre debt level is around $103,000; the income level is about minus $22,000; the average age of farmers is 57; and children are not prepared to accept the responsibilities of the family farm as they have seen their parents struggle and become frustrated by the worry of keeping the farm financially viable. One of the sayings in the bush at the moment is that giving your child the family farm is the ultimate form of child abuse.

PARA.TAB: This rural adjustment package is the second attempt—an unsuccessful attempt—by the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) to produce a package that he believed would be helpful to the farmers of Australia. Unfortunately, as we told him in the debate last year, this package was too immersed in red tape and would not get to all the people out there who require help. That has been very adequately demonstrated by Senator Tambling's contribution to the debate.

This Bill extends benefits already available throughout the States, the Northern Territory and the ACT. That is really a simple administrative matter. The second amendment relates to the provision of assistance for short term problems caused by drought and high interest rates, and that assistance is by way of an interest subsidy for crop planting. The third amendment relates to that crop planting scheme, announced in Prime Minister Keating's One Nation economic statement. An amount of $21m was to be provided for a crop planting scheme to assist, it was estimated, 4,000 cereal and grain farmers, and there was also some provision for hard-pressed sugarcane growers. It was a sort of poor-man's guaranteed minimum price scheme—a way to have a guaranteed minimum price scheme when we did not really have such a scheme.

This planting scheme was introduced at a time when the rural industry was facing very low commodity prices. Trade subsidies were distorting the price of grain, dropping it to $90 or $80 a tonne in the farmer's hands about a year ago. Last year it went up to about $140 a tonne in the grower's hands, when the cost of production was around $150 a tonne. Trade distortions, coupled with very high interest rates of around 27 per cent, have caused massive problems for farmers, and these farmers were then hit again with drought. This scheme was the Government's response to help farmers out.

I do not know whether Senator Tambling mentioned the figures; if he did I will repeat them. There were 356 applications for a 75 per cent interest subsidy; 196 have been approved; 103 have been rejected and 57 are pending. That would indicate there are probably around 200 or 300 people growing grain who need financial assistance. I can assure the Senate there are many more people in absolutely desperate need of assistance. But, as Senator Tambling pointed out, when the farmers turn to the rural adjustment scheme—although the people administering it, I must admit, have been very helpful and have tried to do their best to provide assistance through the scheme—they are told that the gate is just too narrow, the red tape is too deep. Getting into the scheme would require an accountant to prepare an immense set of figures, and that is expensive too. People generally appreciate that it is much better to throw themselves at the mercy of their bank managers and increase their debt rather than chase this scheme around in circles. As I say only 196 applications have been approved.

We told the Minister that at the time he was introducing the scheme. In fact, we pointed out that the rural adjustment scheme was never meant to be a social welfare scheme. The Government has put the rural adjustment scheme in the too hard basket: when nothing else can help farmers, push it into the rural adjustment scheme and let the States administer it. Some States interpret the scheme differently from other States. The scheme has been a monumental failure, although I believe the Minister did intend to make it work.

It reminds me of another scheme that we put in place for desperate farmers at the closing stages of the last Budget session—Job Search. I can recall when we wanted to move amendments the Minister, Senator Richardson, telling us that if we failed to pass the legislation to make destitute farmers eligible for Job Search—and Senator Tambling would remember this—2,000 farmers would be on the door the next day waiting for the Job Search allowance to come through and be it on our heads that these 2,000 farmers would be deprived of getting the Job Search allowance. In his speech, the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think all honourable senators should understand that if some of those amendments which we will cover tonight are passed, they will be rejected in the House of Representatives and the package will not be ready for a couple of thousand farmers who want it to be available on Monday.

We argued for our amendments and we stuck with them. I remember Senator Alston had the passage of the Bill at the time. But as usually happens in this chamber—in about 99 cases out of 100—we stand up for rural Australia, reach a decision, go to the Australian Democrats and argue our case, they agree with us, and then they come in here and collapse under the pressure of some implied threat. It does not happen once; it happens every time. We see it time after time. We have seen it this week probably more than we have ever seen it before: the Democrats collapsed on industrial relations and they collapsed on superannuation. They also collapsed this time last year on the wool Bill when we required a 10 per cent levy, the Government wanted 15 per cent, and the Democrats settled for 12 per cent. That cost farmers an immense amount of money. We were right. About a 9 per cent levy would have actually been required. But the Democrats came in here and, once again, let rural Australia down.

PARA.TAB: Our criticism of that legislation was very well founded. There was $10m allocated to that scheme to assist 2,000 farmers. But let us look at what in reality did happen. We received 134 applications or 134 applicants have managed to receive Job Search under the modified assets test. At the same date, only a little over $200,000 has been spent of that $10m scheme. So again we have seen the Minister trying to help farmers but hopelessly underestimating what rural adjustments would deliver.

I do not criticise the Minister for trying to do what he believed was right but I do criticise him for holding out a carrot of hope for farmers, for lifting their expectation that they will be eligible for some assistance, and then going in and pulling the rug right out from under them. It has happened twice. Here we have a rural adjustment scheme being provided for 4,000 farmers, and about 150 have received assistance. Last year we saw another scheme that was going to help 2,000 farmers, and 134 people have been successful in receiving assistance. That means that $200,000 has been spent out of an allocation of $10m.

We should be looking at that legislation to see where it has failed, but we are not. We just go on and bring in another Bill. The guidelines are so inflexible and complicated that they are a nightmare for the applicants. Not only are they a nightmare for the applicants, but they are also a nightmare for the people who process those applications. I am told that when an application gets through, everyone in the Department cheers because it is so unexpected. The people in the Department are actually trying but the guidelines are so narrow that it is like a camel trying to go through the eye of a needle. So the benefits are not flowing on.

The rural adjustment package was never designed as a social security measure but this Government has used it as such. It has turned the rural adjustment scheme into a bandaid scheme to apply some mythical remedies to the problem. Job Search for farmers has been a disaster and that is evidenced by the fact that although $10m was allocated to help 2,000 farmers, only 134 farmers have received any benefits.

The rural adjustment scheme has not reached the people it was designed to help. This is what we should be looking at now—widening this Bill to reach the people out there who are desperate. I have spoken to some of the people on the Darling Downs, the farm support groups, some belonging to the churches, and I have found that some farmers there are now reliant on food packages. What is happening in Australia is a terrible indictment on the Government. To live, some of our farmers have to rely on food packages handed out by the church or by advisers and community helpers who are financed through the State Government.

I believe that the coalition will have a massive job fixing some of the problems this Government has caused through high interest rates. There are also problems that have not been of the Government's making, one of which is the terrible subsidy war that is causing depressed prices throughout the world. That is not something this Government is responsible for; it is a world event that this Government has had little chance to do anything about. Nevertheless, it is a fact of life that we face terrible trade subsidies right throughout the world. In fact, subsidies on primary industry around the world now amount to $421 billion. Those are the problems that the Government is not addressing and which we must address, as the next coalition Government, in six or seven months time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak for a couple of minutes on the States and Northern Territory Grants (Rural Adjustment) Amendment Bill. I cannot believe it; this concerns the crop planting scheme mentioned by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his economic statement in February 1992, and we are passing the legislation now. The second reading says that some money under part B has been available for crop planting since March 1992. I cannot believe we are putting this legislation through now. Only two days ago the Finn review said that most of the crop planting in the eastern States is complete and even in Western Australia it is 80 per cent complete. I do not quite believe that, but Western Australia is the slowest starting State this year because of the weather. It did not rain much from 25 April until last week. The rest of Australia is supposed to be nearly completed, and here we are putting through legislation.

PARA.TAB: I know the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) says that the money has been available, but I would like to know how much is available. I cannot speak for the eastern States, but the general form of RAFCOR in Western Australia has been that it grants money for planting—to buy seed and fuel or, as in this case, superphosphate—around June, which is late, and, if planting is done then, the chances of getting a good crop come down. The point I make is that, if crop planting was contained in the March 1992 statement, then the legislation should have been introduced far earlier than now, when it is lost in the heap of Bills that have just been introduced in the last couple of weeks.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities on the annual reports of the Australian Securities Commission, the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee, the Companies Auditors and Liquidators Disciplinary Board and the Australian Accounting Standards Board.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present a summary of evidence presented to the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities on the draft Corporate Law Reform Bill 1992. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report and to make a few very brief remarks.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The summary is a result of what I think has been an interesting and quite productive process undertaken by the Committee. In effect, the Committee was acting as a catalyst in organising debate around the draft second Bill, which deals in the main with directors' duties, loans to directors, the question of insolvency and some other matters that ended up not being controversial.

PARA.TAB: As we went around the country hearing from practitioners in the area, we had with us Mr Phillip Noonan from the Attorney-General's Department, who listened to everything that was said, took copious notes and has the transcripts at his disposal, so that he is now in a position to advise the Attorney-General's Department and the Attorney-General on changes that the industry sees as being necessary.

The process worked better than the Attorney-General Department's own attempts at practitioner workshops, because it was seen as the protagonist in what was to some unpopular legislation and it became the subject of personal attack when it held its practitioner workshops in Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide. We went to Perth, Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne and were seen as an independent body which was able to look more objectively and impartially at the whole question. As a result, the level of debate was far more constructive and less personal. The quality of the written and verbal submissions were uniformly high, despite the fact that in some cases not very long notice was given. I commend those who participated in the process for the quality of those submissions. I and the Committee found it a most interesting experience.

I was also heartened—and I think the Committee was too—by the commitment of the Attorney-General early in the process to revisit the legislation and his commitment to make sure that it is rewritten thoroughly so that it does take account of some of the suggestions that have been made by those practitioners in the field. I commend also the Attorney-General's Department itself for its willingness to participate in the process and its apparent willingness to really look seriously at sensible amendments to the legislation.

We will be going through a similar process in relation to the Close Corporations Act which was passed by the Parliament but has never been proclaimed because of some constitutional difficulties. The Committee will take that Bill around the country in much the same way, but, in addition, in that case we will be looking at a very thorough rewrite to make it a much simpler Act than it is currently.

It deals with small business and has to be understood by small business, which is less likely than the larger corporations to be able to seek legal advice. With the Close Corporations Act we will be repeating the process that we have just engaged in with the second draft of the corporations Bill. I commend that process to the Senate as a very useful mechanism. We are looking forward to that exposure in August and September of this year.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! Before calling Senator Lewis, I note that this debate will be interrupted at 11.55 a.m., and that two senators are seeking the call.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I recognise the significance of your comment. I would also like to congratulate the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) for allowing the Corporate Law Reform Bill 1992 to lie on the table, for allowing opportunities for people who are practising in this area to express their views both to the Attorney-General's office and to our Committee, and for his commitment to the reform of that legislation. I was delighted to read in one of today's newspapers that in a press release the Attorney-General has foreshadowed a major review of company law to make it simpler and easier to understand.

PARA.TAB: All of the witnesses who came before us would support that proposal wholeheartedly, as would the members of the Committee. That is not to say that the task will be easy. This relatively short paper—in comparison with the volume of legislation that the Committee looked at—has been prepared to enable honourable senators to understand some of the major problems which confront companies and directors of companies in today's corporate law area.

Mr John Green, a partner in Freehill, Hollingdale and Page in Sydney, has said that there has been a fundamental shift and we are going the wrong way with regard to our company law in that, instead of directors assessing whether the company should do something and how that would benefit the company, they are now asking themselves whether the company will go on to do a particular thing and, if so, what will be the personal risk attached to it.

Of course, it is a matter of grave concern that, with our desperate need to become internationally competitive, directors of companies in Australia are not able to think of ways whereby a company can progress itself forward without constantly worrying about covering their backsides, if I might use that expression, to ensure that they do not end up being prosecuted for some offence in relation to the massive and extensive corporate legislation by one of the many agencies that have been established to supervise it.

That then leads us to the very difficult question of whether the law should be what is called black letter law or whether it should be fuzzy law. Differences of opinion have been expressed in that area by witnesses who came before the Committee. The solution to that might very well lie with the Victorian Law Reform Commission, which is coming up with principles of parliamentary legislative drafting which I think have great merit. Those principles rest upon the idea that the first sentence of a clause of a Bill will express the purpose of that clause—what that clause is hoping to achieve. All subclauses of that clause will be in relation to the primary statement—the principles set out in the first clause. The legislation may even use examples to explain what is meant by the principle which is established in the first paragraph of the particular clause or part of the Act.

I think there will be enormous advantages to all of us if parliamentary draftsmen can go down that road. Our Committee is looking at doing something along those lines with regard to the Close Corporations Act. I hope that we will be able to demonstrate to the Parliament the major benefits of this procedure when we bring the Close Corporations Act before the Senate.

I wish to say how much I appreciated the evidence given to us by many of the witnesses and the problems that they raised with us. During the last day of Committee hearings in Melbourne one of the most significant things that were raised was the fact that Australian corporations law seems to be getting out of line with our international competitors. That means that some international companies will not register to trade in Australia because of the difficulties of our corporations law and because of the consequences for directors of their companies under Australian corporate law. We must always be careful that, in our concerns about what has happened with corporations in the last decade, we do not get to the stage where Australian corporations law is so far out of kilter with international corporations law that it is to the detriment of this nation's trade.

I have only a couple of minutes left. The only other matter I wish to raise is the question of disclosure—in particular, the disclosure of loans to directors. There are many paragraphs in the Bill dealing with loans to directors. One of our witnesses said that, when he read these clauses in relation to loans to directors, he threw up his hands in horror and said, `As far as I'm concerned, in my companies there will be no further loans to directors'. I can well understand him adopting that approach.

But that could very well be a major problem which ought not to be allowed. For example, clearly some executive directors ought to be given loans to enable them to purchase their homes in relocated sites. For example, if a chief executive officer was relocated from Adelaide, where the price of housing is relatively low, to Sydney, where home prices are very high, as part of that person's executive salary package he or she ought to be granted a substantial loan to enable him or her to purchase a home in Sydney. That should be available.

The point that I wish to raise is that, whilst the companies are talking about the difficulties in these areas, none of them are making voluntary disclosures. I suggest that some of our public companies ought to see that there would be much merit in making voluntary disclosure of all sorts of information in regard to their directors and executive directors such as the size, details and specifics of loans which have been made to directors, the salaries that have been paid and any other perks of office. I am sure that if some companies were to show the way in this regard—in other words, with full voluntary disclosure—those companies may very well find themselves much more successful on the stock exchange than the present situation where most companies simply reveal the information which they are required to reveal under the statutory requirements of our corporations legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of our Committee, the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, in congratulating and thanking those people who provided evidence during our hearings. As Senator Beahan, the Chairman of the Committee, said, the written evidence and the oral evidence that the Committee took in Perth, Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne was of a uniformly high standard. It added to the Committee members' understanding of the complex nature of this legislation, of the law reform task and of the problems faced by the business community and the professional community in dealing with this extremely complicated and, indeed in some places, onerous legislation.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Lewis has pointed out, one of the most concerning matters was highlighted in our Melbourne hearings on the last day of our around Australia bandwagon—the matter of international competitive advantage. Even though it was reflected in all of the other hearings, it was put very well by one of the witnesses in Melbourne that Australia is in an international environment, corporations are increasingly international in focus, trans-global, trans-national corporations, and that Australia should, particularly in the South East Asian region, be trying to attract its fair share of head offices to the capital cities of Australia to increase Australia's employment chances.

Evidence was given that New Zealand, for example, had looked at the Australian model and had rejected it. In Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaysia and South East Asia generally, Australia's governance of corporations was seen to be far too onerous, far too black letter and far too heavily regulated. Australia was seen as having slipped behind in this important area of legislation and international competitive advantage because of the black letter, prescriptive approach that corporations legislation has taken in Australia.

When we are looking at this so-called corporate law reform Bill, we note that it is going even further. The overwhelming weight of the evidence, which is well summarised in this document, shows that this over-regulated approach is strongly rejected by the business community, by the company directors, by the business people and, of course, by the professionals who have to deal with the legislation.

The overwhelming comment was that directors, officers of companies, people who have to deal and comply with this corporations law, can no longer do so because it is so complicated and so weighty that it is almost impossible to understand. If it is impossible to understand the law, it is very hard to comply with it.

One of the final points I wanted to make, in the very short time I have remaining to me, relates to the approach of compliance, and to the costs of compliance to business in Australia. We hear in this place day after day about the sorts of burdens faced by the business community in complying with taxation legislation and all sorts of other government legislative requirements. This proposed law reform contains a massive increase in the paper compliance cost to business, particularly in relation to the disclosure of loans to directors and transactions between related companies. Indeed, this legislation calls for immediate disclosure of all such transactions. One of the matters raised all around Australia was: how can the Australian Securities Commission, firstly, deal with the information that it will be receiving and, secondly, what is the benefit to Australia generally, to the national interest, of disclosing all of this legislation?

The summary of evidence shows that the business community and the professional community see a lot of this so-called law reform as unnecessary and as an over-reaction, not to a failure in the law—the point is well made in this evidence—but to a failure to enforce the law. One of the points that were made in Brisbane very clearly by company directors in that city was that there needs to be a moratorium on changes to this legislation because the business community has not come to grips with the enormous changes brought about with the establishment of the new centralised scheme and the Australian Securities Commission just over a year ago. It was felt that there should be a moratorium on change so that the Australian business community can come to grips with the legislation we have already. The Joint Statutory Committee, of which Senator Beahan is the Chairman, has played a vital role in raising the level of debate on these issues.

PARA.TAB: The New Zealand industrial relations legislation provides for a minimum wage for full time adult workers—but it is a very low minimum. Other conditions and payments—such as hours of work, penalty rates, shift arrangements and any other allowances—must also be negotiated with the employer.

It is very important to note that in concomitant social security changes, workers who resign or refuse job offers cannot qualify for unemployment benefits for six months. This has dramatically further reduced the bargaining power of employees in dealing with employers. An employer can force a wage cut onto workers; if the worker refuses to take the cut and leaves the job, he or she will not qualify for the dole.

I go back to the debate about young workers which is about to beset us after lunch. There is no minimum wage at all for young workers in New Zealand. An employer can insist on paying a young worker below the level of the dole. If the young worker does not then accept the rate below the dole, he or she is cut off from unemployment benefits for six months. That is supposed to be a system of equity, fairness and security. It is the model for the Opposition's industrial relations policy. What hope would there be for young workers if that were to be introduced in Australia?

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Approximately 40 people were killed in an attack by hostel dwellers believed to be, though not yet confirmed, Inkatha supporters. I am sure that all Australians would be outraged to learn that many of the dead were women and children. It is tragic that over 80 lives have been lost this week, bringing the tally this year to over 1,400 people killed.

PARA.TAB: I am aware that the ANC has charged the Government with complicity in yesterday's killings, saying that police and security forces assisted in the attack. These charges are under investigation by a Supreme Court judge, Justice Goldstone. If the allegations are confirmed, Australia will of course condemn to the authorities in the strongest possible terms.

It is important that the international community not turn a blind eye to this terrible bloodshed. Australia will be discussing, with its Commonwealth partners and others, what if anything more the international community can do to help bring an end to the violence and to support a return to the negotiating table. The ANC Secretary-General, Cyril Ramaphosa, said that actions like these could lead to the negotiations being derailed, and that is a self-evident proposition. We sincerely hope that will not be the case. Political differences should be settled at the negotiating table and not in bloody conflict.

While, no doubt, the campaign of mass action recently initiated by the ANC in response to the political stalemate has contributed to the climate of tension now evident in South Africa, it is the case that the ANC, along with all other parties, has the right of non-violent, peaceful protest. We simply hope that this course of protest that is occurring at the moment will not itself serve to undermine the climate for negotiations. Once again, the Australian Government calls on all parties to demonstrate a spirit of reconciliation and compromise so that a peaceful settlement can be achieved as speedily as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. It follows the question asked of him by Senator Pat Giles in respect of New Zealand's industrial relations. I draw Senator Cook's attention to the strike at Hamersley Iron in his own State of Western Australia which involves more than 2,000 workers and which threatens to become the biggest at Hamersley Iron in almost a decade—a strike caused by a worker's refusal to join the Metal and Engineering Workers Union. Does he agree with the union organiser, John Mossenton, that the worker is a parasite on society and has inflicted pain on his fellow workers as well as the reputation of Hamersley, all for the $160 membership which is tax deductible anyway? Is this an example of Labor's industrial relations at work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —We are, of course, very consistent on the subject of industrial disputes. This is an industrial dispute, as I understand it, in the Pilbara about whether a person should be a member of a union or not. The view I express about that dispute is that the proper place for it to be settled is the Industrial Relations Commission and that it is not appropriate that there be any disruption of production at Hamersley Iron if there is a grievance to be settled over this issue of union membership. I say that because it is my understanding that the agreements—these are not awards—concluded between Hamersley Iron and its work force provide preference for union membership and it is something that both parties, Hamersley Iron and its work force, have agreed on. We now have a dispute over whether the provision of the agreement—this is the parties interacting together, not with the presence of a third party—is being properly handled. Whether it is or it is not, it should go to the Arbitration Commission to be settled.

PARA.TAB: Since Senator Crichton-Browne's introduction was about New Zealand, let me draw a comparison. What I said in my answer about New Zealand was that the first thing the Employment Contracts Act did was abolish the arbitration commission in New Zealand and terminate the awards of that commission. If that were transmogrified across the Tasman to Australia, it would mean that there would be no umpire to settle the dispute over an agreement between an employer and its employees. The dispute would rage unchecked without there being a chance to settle it by going to the merits of the case and it could only then be settled by going to who is the strongest industrial power—the employer, in this case, or the union. That is exactly what the arbitration system proposes to circumvent; it proposes to concentrate on the merits of the issue rather than the industrial strength of the parties.

I am asked whether I support the remarks Senator Crichton-Browne has said are attributed to Mr Mossenton. I understand the chagrin of union members when they pay for the negotiations of an agreement and then other people come along later, without making a contribution, and take up the advantage that has been achieved by that negotiation. But I do not think the chagrin is sufficient to cause this disruption of production and, as I say, the matter should go to the Arbitration Commission for settlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Cook will know, of course, that the agreement has been superseded by an amendment to the Western Australian arbitration Act. Senator Cook has not told us whether he believes in voluntary unionism or not. He has not told us whether or not he believes in the right of individuals to contract their labour with employers. What he has told us is that this is a good example of unions and corporations doing deals and the last consideration is the workers. I ask Senator Cook: does he support the Western Australian Industrial Relations Act, which makes it an offence to dismiss a worker on the ground of union membership; or does he support the Western Australian Labor Minister for Industrial Relations, who is on the side of the union and the workers and contrary to the interest of this particular worker?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there were a logical base or a logical thread here it would help in this discussion. The reason why a person cannot be dismissed on the ground of union membership as a provision of the Act is to prevent people from being victimised because they join a trade union, which is not the way in which Senator Crichton-Browne in this question has tried to present the facts. It is my understanding that the company is arguing that the agreement it has entered into is superseded by a provision not in the arbitration Act but in another Act about non-discrimination. It seems to me that if that is the case in point it ought to go before the umpire for the umpire to rule whether an agreement between the parties can be superseded by a provision in another Act, and whether that provision is in fact relevant to these circumstances. It is not for me to take a position on who is right or wrong about that. The parties should present their case and have it determined.
—This is all about voluntary unionism.
—Order!

—The third point Senator Crichton-Browne asked me was whether I agree that employers should be able to contract with their employees. I do not know what he thinks an agreement between the unions, representing the employees, and the employer is. The agreement is in fact the contract of employment for the employees in this particular company. That is its legal status; it provides the contract of employment terms. It is an industrial agreement between the unions, representing those workers, and the company. If Senator Crichton-Browne could understand these basic and fundamental points of industrial law and come to grips with them, then perhaps he would understand how erroneous, wrong and misleading are a lot of the allegations that are made by his shadow spokesman, Mr John Howard, about industrial relations performance in this country.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. In the light of the Queensland Government's announced commitment to train young Australians to work as guides for the Japanese tourist industry, will the Minister seek discussions between the Queensland Government and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to review the viability of issuing work visas to 2,000 Japanese nationals who could disadvantage other job seekers, especially in areas of high unemployment like Cairns and the Whitsunday regions?

—Senator Reynolds, by her question, gives an impression that a decision has been taken which ought to be reviewed. It has to be emphasised that no decision has been taken on the request, I understand, by wholesale tour operators, mostly in Queensland, that a number of Japanese be brought in in order to act as tourist guides for the great influx of Japanese tourists, particularly into Queensland, but to other parts of Australia also. It has to be said very firmly that no decision has been taken on that application. But I do believe that it is very important to indicate that the consultations which are essential before such an agreement is reached are being undertaken, and they are being undertaken by the trade union movement, by the tour operators and by various Federal government departments. This is not something which will be dictated to governments by tour operators. It is a matter which requires, as I have said, the fullest consultation with trade unions, which are of course concerned with protecting the employment prospects of their members and of those who might enter the work force as Australian members of their unions and others.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, it also must be emphasised that in discussions and consultations of this sort, the question of the undertakings by the industry itself to provide training and job opportunities for people to act as guides for tourists coming to Australia will be absolutely paramount. In the absence of such undertaking, no permission would be given; I can assure Senator Lewis of that. Labour agreements are all about providing training and employment opportunities to Australians. In fact, that sort of undertaking must be given by the industry before such visa applications will even be countenanced.

Japanese-based travel companies and their wholesale operators here in Australia have put forward a proposal. As I say, that proposal has certainly not received assent by the Federal Government. It requires commitment by governments. Senator Reynolds mentions the Queensland Government being prepared to offer training programs to enable young Queenslanders to enter into this tourist guide activity and employment. That sort of commitment is a very recently announced interest of the Queensland Government. It is good that the Queensland Government is prepared to help train young Queenslanders to get those job opportunities. We certainly encourage that and we are quite prepared to speak to the Queensland Government in the context of these consultations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister mentioned consultations, and that is very good to hear. Could he ask the Minister to ensure that consultations include consultations with youth advocacy services and the Unemployed Workers Union?

—I cannot give an undertaking as to whether particular groups will be involved in the discussions, but I assure the honourable senator that we are very conscious of the need to provide employment opportunities in the tourist industry for young Australians. That is why the industry, in making this application and in the consultations that are occurring, has to understand that its commitment to providing those job opportunities and the training that is required to enable people to take up job opportunities is absolutely fundamental to the industry getting anywhere in its application.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Additional Information for Senator Peter Cook

PARA.TAB: Yesterday Senator Calvert asked me a Question Without Notice, in my capacity as the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, on the Tasmanian wool industry. I undertook to seek further information on this matter.
The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided me with the following additional information:

ANSWER.PARA: "Proposals to improve the way wool is sold have been the subject of consistent industry comment for many years and gained importance during the industry restructuring of 1990-91.

The Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) has established a Wool Industry Advisory Committee (WIAC) to examine, inter alia, wool selling systems, including the possible rationalisation of wool selling centres, in order to achieve improvements in the efficiency of marketing wool. WIAC comprises representatives of the Wool Council of Australia, the Australian Council of Wool Exporters, the National Council of Wool Selling Brokers of Australia, the Federal Council of Private Treaty Wool merchants and the Australian Wool Processors Council.
WIAC has recommended a reduction in the number of wool auction centres as a means of improving the efficiency of the wool selling system.

The proposal is that a minimum offering of 25,000 bales be required to hold a sale, based on a judgement by WIAC in its wool selling program guidelines that this amount constitutes a national minimum level for a viable wool sale.

The issue is obviously a sensitive one. The Government appreciates the importance of Launceston as a major selling centre for Tasmanian wool but it should be made clear that neither the Government nor the AWC have the power to close selling centres—the AWC's role is to facilitate, not enforce, reforms.
Decisions on the fate of individual selling centres will be industry decisions and I would expect that such decisions will be based on a sound economic rationale.

PARA.TAB: As I indicated in my answer to Senator Calvert yesterday, the Government recognises the high quality superfine wool that Tasmania produces. This product is acknowledged as among the best in the world.

It is in demand by the European fashion houses, particularly in Italy and France. The Government commends the continuing high quality wool that Tasmania produces. It adds significantly to our exports and balance of trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Crichton-Browne on 19 June 1992 relating to Hamersley Iron.

SPEECH.PARA: The very essence of Senator Cook's answer highlighted all the concerns that we have expressed in respect of the recent legislation. The truth of the matter is that this dispute has been about the right of individual workers to seek employment without the need to be associated with a union. Senator Cook referred to the fact that a previous agreement was entered into between Hamersley Iron and the union. That is absolutely true. The agreement entered into by Hamersley Iron with the union was that preference would be given to unionists. That agreement is a classic example of an agreement entered into without consideration to individual rights. It is an agreement entered into in the interests of the union. The company agreed to it because it virtually had no choice.

PARA.TAB: What the company used to do—as Senator Cook well knows—was that when a worker refused to join the union or resigned from the union during his term of employment, he was promptly sacked by the company, because the price of sacking the worker was cheaper than the company involving itself in industrial disputation. As the Minister well knows, the Act was amended and those amendments supersede the agreement of 1982. It is now an offence to dismiss a worker who is no longer a member of a union.

Notwithstanding the Act, the workers and the union, aided and abetted by the Labor Minister for Industrial Relations in Western Australia, embarked upon the largest strike in a decade at Hamersley Iron. It includes Dampier, Mount Tom Price and Paraburdoo and it will bring that company to its knees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek your ruling for the sake of consistency. This morning you upheld a point of order that I raised. During a debate last night I raised the same point of order with the Deputy President, who refused to uphold my point of order. I would like your ruling on that particular incident.

—It has been ruled on several occasions by my predecessors that it is not in order for a senator to refer to another senator as a disgrace or a disgrace to the Senate. I intend to follow those appropriate precedents, and I will not permit the expression to be used.

PARA.TAB: I also take the opportunity to say that my predecessors also ruled on several occasions that it was not in order for a senator to call another senator a hypocrite. This expression has been used frequently in interjections recently. I will also not permit it to be used, if I hear it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak only for the minute I asked for. I just say to Senator Cook, through you, Mr President, that this disputation in the Pilbara which is closing down a multimillion dollar industry, causing 2,000 men to be without pay, without income and, for the time being, without jobs, is not as a result of variations, interpretations and understandings of agreements or contracts. It is simply about one man's right to work without being bound to pay a union membership fee. This is a man who simply wants to work without being coerced, intimidated, threatened or caused in any circumstance to have to join a union for that right to work for a living. That is what this dispute is about.

PARA.TAB: In the past the company has found it easier simply to sack people who had the courage to stand up and say, `I do not want to be in this union'. Those people were sacked, not because the company believed in it, not because the company wanted it, but because the company was prepared to pay that price for peace. As Senator Cook knows, subsequently the Western Australian arbitration Act was amended to make it an offence for companies to dismiss workers because they did not continue to be members of a union.

This man has decided that he does not want to be a member of the union. He wants to get on with his life. He wants to go to work each day, free and unfettered from any coercion to join any association or any organisation. Mr Mossenton—this thug, this bully, this brute—describes this man who simply wants to go to work and mind his own business as a parasite on society. Mr Mossenton blames him for inflicting pain on his fellow workers as well as on the reputation of Hamersley Iron, as he calls it. This is Mr Mossenton's understanding of freedom, liberty and rights. He says, `All for a $160 membership, which is tax deductible anyway'. Mr Mossenton has boiled down this man's right to work, this man's right to dissociate himself from the union, this man's right to go about his ordinary daily affairs without being intimidated on this: all it is about is $160 which is tax deductible.

It has not occurred to this union official—who, by the way, lives on the $160 that is taken out of the workers' pay packets—that there is something grander than the contemplation of $160 a year membership fee; there is a finer ideal, a finer principle, a higher motive. It has not occurred to Mr Mossenton that this man simply wants the right not to join a union. This man wants to preserve the liberty of which this country has been so proud for so long. The price for this man standing up and having the courage to so do is that the billion dollar operation in the Hamersley Ranges in the Pilbara has closed down. The operations at Tom Price, Paraburdoo and Dampier have closed down simply because one man said, `I don't want to join your union'.

I conclude by saying that the fundamental objection the Opposition has to the Minister's legislation in respect of contractors is that it is an arrangement between employers and the unions. Senator Cook does not see a part in the world for the individual who wants to contract his own labour, his own skills, his own ability and his own endeavour directly, personally and privately to his employers. The problem with this legislation is that the Government is now taking away from ordinary, individual contractors their right to so contract their labour, their efforts or their enterprise. The Government sees the unions as corporate Australia—the two bigs get together and there is no room in between for the little man.

There was a time at the end of the last century when the Labor Party came together because it believed in the rights of the individual; it believed in the rights of individual people to work, to aspire, to gain rewards and to achieve their goals, aspirations, wishes and desires. Members of the Labor Party used to believe in that; that is why they came together and formed the Labor Party. That is where it got its name. Now it is corporate Australia. Its care is for that monolithic structure of a union movement that runs its daily life and agenda. That is why this country is in the mess that it is in, and that is why the Minister's once fine Party is in such disarray and decay. Tragically, the real price is being paid by the ordinary guy on the floor of the factory, the shop or the mine.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crichton-Browne for the lecture from a conservative—I say that in an effort to be accurate about his political complexion, not as a form of abuse—about the failings of the Labor Party. I do not accept the criticism because we do stand by our ideals. I will address the issue of the rights of the individual, which is fundamental to our world view and our basic philosophy and is fundamental to this question.

PARA.TAB: Before I turn to the substance of the subject, the reference made to contractors by Senator Crichton-Browne is, with due respect, ill-informed because there is no provision in that Bill that people need be members of a union at all. The only provision is that, if people are working on a contract which is harsh and unfair, they have a means, easily and accessibly, to have that contract reviewed. I would have thought that is a principle of the right of the individual. If people are victims of a harsh and unfair contract, they ought to be able to have a means by which, whether they are union members or not, they can have that contract reviewed.

The current Hamersley Iron dispute is a dispute that Australia does not need and that we ought not to have. I enjoin those unions involved in it to return to work and settle their differences directly with the company through the means of the Arbitration Commission. At lunchtime it was reported to me that, as we speak, there is a conference before Commissioner Fielding of the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission to resolve the matter. He has indicated that should it not be resolved, he will order a settlement of the matter. This is the proper procedures of the Commission functioning. I make the point—although it is not germane to this debate—that, if the Opposition's industrial relations policy applied, the Commission would not be able to act in this way.

After an investigation that I conducted over lunchtime, the circumstances of this dispute appear to me to be that Hamersley Iron reached an agreement with its unions on behalf of its employees in 1982. That agreement reflected, in the terms of the agreement concluded between the parties, a provision that, in order to work on Hamersley Iron sites, people had to be members of the relevant unions. That was an agreement entered into between the company and the unions. It may well be that people have various reasons, misgivings or qualifications about entering into an agreement, but there is no argument that this agreement was voluntarily entered into by the parties who are, therefore, bound by it.

In December 1982, the Western Australian Industrial Relations Act was amended by the then Liberal Government. The provisions in the Act relating to the ability of registered industrial relations agreements to contain such a provision were removed. As a consequence, it seems plain that once the provisions of the Act are gone, ergo, so are the provisions of the agreement. That was the impact of that change to industrial law in Western Australia as I recall the debate in 1982.

So it would seem that the agreements concluded between the parties were altered by government intervention in the law of industrial relations to prevent the parties concluding an agreement on this matter. As a consequence, between then and now the parties have managed their relationship harmoniously on this front and without disputation. Until now, some nine years later, I have not been aware of any dispute about this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is because you have a no ticket, no start policy.

—I am coming to the issue. So it seems on the face of it that the proceedings before Commissioner Fielding should be allowed to proceed in an effort to conciliate this dispute. If that cannot be done, he has undertaken to take particular action under the powers of the Act.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crichton-Browne has raised this issue not to one of the facts or the law, although doubtless he had regard to those, but to a moral plain. He has raised this to a plain of `the finer ideals'—the motives and principles generated in this society. On that basis he has referred to the Labor Party and its ideals.

This is a different matter from the law. There are those who can distinguish between what is lawful and what is justice. If I had been in government in Western Australia in 1982, I would not have enacted the changes to the Act that the conservative Liberal-National Party Government in Western Australia did. However, that Government was in power and it did that.

The Western Australian upper House is a gerrymandered chamber and the Labor Government which has occupied the treasury bench in that State since 1983 has not been able to repeal the changes because of that unfair gerrymander and the conservative dominated upper House. So the law has remained intact. The important thing to reflect upon in this sense is that it is the law of the Liberal-National Party, not the law of the Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it is a good law.

—No, it is not a good law in my view. Having said that, in entering this debate on the high moral plain that Senator Crichton-Browne has invited me to, I should say that the first obligation of people is to obey the law whether they agree with it or not. If people do not agree with the law and they take action outside it, they have to expect to be penalised. So the first point is whether people ought to obey the law—and in my view they should.

PARA.TAB: However, Senator Crichton-Browne has invited me to debate the issue of individual rights. He says that this is a case in which an individual has a superior right to any other individual. He says that because this person wishes to accept and benefit from the particularly advantageous conditions negotiated by unions on behalf of their members—and the pay rises that will inevitably follow at a level more advantageous to the rest of the community—then that person has a right to do so irrespective of the collective rights of every other individual who works on that site and who has participated in the negotiation of those conditions. This is a question, therefore, of the right of one person and the right of several thousand other persons.

On the evaluation of rights, who in these circumstances has the superior right? Those opposite conclude that the one individual has the clear right over the majority. I conclude that the majority have the clear right. One of the terms of the particular agreement prescribes that, if one is going to get the benefits of that agreement, one ought to contribute towards the cost of obtaining it. It is the right of that group that I regard frankly and openly as the superior one in this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Animal Farm! Who is the pig?

—It is not Animal Farm; it is a question of straight-out democracy and the weighing of the particular values of rights. I conclude my reply by saying that that is not the law in Western Australia, and the law should be obeyed. I hope that Commissioner Fielding, in the exercise of his office, is able to bring about a reconciliation. There is no doubt that this is a damaging economic dispute, because this is a key export industry. In this dispute, as in all others, there are two parties. To single out one party for exclusive blame and attention, as the Opposition does, is to take an unbalanced and biased view of proceedings. I take the view that there are two parties; it takes two parties to make a dispute, and the mechanisms of the Commission are in place to reconcile it. I hope they do. The obligation remains on both parties, not just one, to resolve this matter.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I propose that the following matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion:

PROCTEXT.PARA: `The Government's refusal to acknowledge the extent of Australia's youth unemployment disaster which the Prime Minister is now trying to disguise, and its failure to take effective action to fix it.'
