PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

EMPHASIS.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

TALK.START.PARA: —As youth affairs spokesman in the Senate, I welcome the participation of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, in this debate. It appears that at last the Government is taking this subject seriously. The subject we are debating is the Government's refusal to acknowledge the extent of Australia's youth unemployment disaster, which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is now trying to disguise, and its failure to take effective action to fix it.

PARA.TAB: Let us get the facts straight first-up. I plead with the Government to deal with the facts in this debate and not the fancies that the Prime Minister is presently spreading around. Let us get rid of the Government's dishonest propaganda that the real youth unemployment rate is only about 10 per cent—lower than the official adult rate—because this is simply disgraceful and dishonest. It is a fiddling of the figures. It is aimed at disguising what Mr Keating, either as Treasurer or Prime Minister, has done to young Australians.

But at least this fiddling with the figures explains why Mr Keating and his Government have done nothing to fix it. They do not even know that it is happening. It is only 10 per cent, according to the Government. The truth is that, far from the official figures overstating the crisis, as Mr Keating and his mate Senator Cook are now pretending, the official unemployment figures massively understate the extent of the youth unemployment disaster.

I hope the Government has a look at these figures when it is dealing with this matter. When the official figures released as a result of recent Australian Bureau of Statistics surveys of not only unemployment but also hidden unemployment and underemployment are added to the official unemployment figures, they show that one in every two 15- to 19-year-olds wanting to work is either unemployed or underemployed. That represents about one in every three of Australia's total youth population. That includes all those who are in full time education and who are not available for work. It deals with the very objection that Senator Cook and Mr Keating are making to the official statistics. One in three of the total youth population of Australia is either jobless or underemployed. Let Senator Button or anyone else deny those official ABS survey results.

This unemployment and underemployment rate for youths is far higher than the rate for adults on a similar basis, but let us recognise that adult employment is a disaster as well. We are concentrating on the youth unemployment situation because of the Government's campaign of deception in trying to tell the Australian public that because more young people are staying on at school, many of them funded by Austudy, to keep them out of the unemployment queues—it will have one effect: it will make better educated dole queues—therefore, the official figures put out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics are somehow no longer relevant.

The Government is also trying to pretend that things were even worse for teenagers in the 1983 recession. That is just self-evident bunkum. Let us look at the facts. There are now 26,000 more young people unemployed—that is including the hidden unemployed—than in the same month in 1983. There are now 75,000 more young people unemployed or underemployed than in 1983. The figures are clear, unequivocal, and cannot be denied, even by Mr Keating or Senator Cook with their remarkable ability to cook the books.

This is how it has happened: the Government has cut the teenage work force since 1983 by about 50,000 by doing what, in many instances, will be a useful exercise—encouraging more and more young people to stay on longer at school and become better qualified. But this reduction in the teenage work force should have brought a massive reduction in competition for jobs and, therefore, a big cut in unemployment. That simply has not happened, because over that time the total number of young unemployed has only edged down by 1,000, yet there are 50,000 fewer of them in the work force.

Of course, what has happened is that over this time the number of full time jobs filled by 15- to 19-year-old Australians has been slashed by just under 200,000. Jobs have simply been wiped out. Some of them have been replaced by part time jobs. That is why the official unemployment rate has soared. It cannot be explained by the Government's structural changes to education. The reason youth unemployment has soared is that jobs have been decimated. This has been particularly so over the last two years of the recession we had to have. In fact, the unemployment situation was holding up reasonably well until the last couple of years and then, all of a sudden, there was decimation.

The youth jobs crisis is turning into a catastrophe that is already even worse now for young people than in the Great Depression of the 1930s. By May this year, there were jobs available for one in every three 16- to 19-year-olds looking for full time work, and in Victoria and South Australia the official youth jobless rate hit a record-breaking 45 per cent.

Even if those who are prepared to put up with only part time work are included, the youth unemployment rate in May this year was almost 25 per cent—one in four. That is far higher than the comparable census figure of around 20 per cent in the Depression year of 1933. As a result of that, young Australians aged 15 to 19 now make up one in every five of Australia's total unemployed, compared with only one in seven in the middle of the Great Depression.

Although the latest official unemployment figures for 15- to 19-year-old Australians are the worst ever recorded, as I said earlier, they hide the hidden unemployed and underemployment that, according to recent ABS surveys, have lifted total youth unemployment and underemployment to 2 1/2 times the official jobless level. I say again, because the Government does not seem to have grasped this, that these official ABS surveys indicate that one in every two 15- to 19-year-olds wanting to work is either unemployed or underemployed—about one third or something like 426,000 of Australia's total youth population of 1.3 million.

This is the reality of the youth jobs disaster that the Federal Government pretends is not nearly as bad. We can see that, on the contrary, it is even worse. This is not simply because of the hidden unemployment and the underemployment that we can see; it also stems absolutely clearly from the decimation of youth jobs that has taken place during this recession we had to have.

After seven years, during which time the number of full time teenage jobs had remained fairly constant, suddenly over two years of the recession, to May of this year, more than two in every five youth jobs were wiped out by this Government. The number of youth jobs slumped from about 410,000 to fewer than 250,000. Two years ago, 31 per cent of all 15- to 19-year-olds had full time jobs. That is not going back to the last recession; it is simply two years ago. Under this Government, that figure has been slashed: only 19 per cent of young people have full time jobs.

The 162,000 full time jobs that were lost over this time made up almost half of Australia's total of 366,000 full time jobs destroyed in the recession in the two years to May. So, although 15- to 19-year-olds make up only 5.6 per cent of Australia's full time labour force, they account for 44 per cent of all full time job losses.

The young people of Australia are clearly in the firing line of Mr Keating's engineered recession—the recession that we had to have. With the population of young Australians aged 15 to 19 having fallen by about 75,000 over the past two years, in normal times the number of unemployed should also have fallen. Instead, it has jumped over the two years by something like 42,000 young people. Without this recession, job prospects should have improved considerably for 15- to 19-year-olds over these two years, as a slump in their numbers, as I said, should have reduced the competition for available jobs. The extension of Austudy to increasing numbers of students should have reduced that competition even further. In any event, the recent rises in youth unemployment go nowhere near accounting for the huge job losses of the last two years. The 40,000-odd lift in full time jobless to 125,000 in May this year represents less than a quarter of the total number of jobs lost over the last two years.

So what has happened? These young Australians, who have disappeared from the unemployment statistics, dramatise the existence of an army of hidden youth unemployed who want jobs but who are excluded from the figures because they have given up trying, along with all those other underemployed young Australians who have to put up with inadequate part time work. We can see here that the figures do not include all these people. They do not include the people who work for more than one hour a week for nothing on their family farms or in their family businesses. These figures massively understate the horror—and yet this Government is going around pretending, for disgusting political purposes, that the figures somehow overstate the reality.

A recent ABS survey has shown that just under 100,000 15- to 19-year-olds are underemployed, giving an underemployment rate of about 13 per cent. Another figure for last September reveals that there are 160,000 or so who are not listed as unemployed but who would prefer to work and who would be available to work if jobs were available. Altogether, these Bureau of Statistics surveys show a total of officially unemployed and hidden unemployed of about 335,000. If the official underemployed are added in as well, you end up with a horrific total of about 435,000 young Australians, of whom, as I said earlier, one in every two want to work but are being denied the job opportunities they seek in the recession we had to have.

As a proportion of the total 15- to 19-year-old population, even including those in full time education who are not available for work, the figure represents one in every three young Australians. So the lost generation is no myth; it is a devastating reality, and there seems little hope that anything will happen to change this in the near future. It would take a 67 per cent rise in the total number of youth jobs to accommodate the 335,000 hidden unemployed, let alone the 100,000 underemployed, and there is no prospect of such an unprecedented rise in youth job opportunities under the present policies. Of course, there are opportunities under Fightback, but that is the only set of proposals that offers any hope to young Australians. Where will the jobs come from to cope with the remaining half a million young Australians who are, at present, simply pressing on with their studies in the hope of getting a job one day? For it is in the schools that today's submerged crisis is now building up to tomorrow's disaster.

Another serious problem is hidden in the recession's huge increase in the proportion of young Australians having to make do with part time work. Youth is also in the firing line of long term unemployment. Although 15- to 19-year-olds represent less than 10 per cent of the Australian population aged 15 and over, less than 9 per cent of the total labour force and only 5.6 per cent of the full time labour force, they account for 14 per cent of the number of long term unemployed—which is far greater than their proportion in either the work force or the population.

Pretending, as the Keating Government does, that the youth unemployment rate is around only 10 per cent, against the reality that one in every two 15- to 19-year-olds wanting to work and one in every three of the total youth population is either officially unemployed, in the hidden unemployed or underemployed may hide the problem, but it will do nothing to solve it. This may explain why the Government had done nothing to fix up this crisis which has been evident for the past 12 months until last week's belated call for yet another summit, another talkfest, another do-nothing option. At least this may mean that the Government has ceased believing its own propaganda and has at last recognised that this crisis must be resolved. Under Fightback and the Opposition's policies, it would be resolved.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is what this speech is all about: under Fightback all of these problems would be fixed. Senator Michael Baume has come in here and made his speech in a voice dramatic with the horror of it all. He used the exact same voice to make six smearing speeches during the week about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). He used exactly the same voice and exactly the same sort of rhetoric. Whoever wrote that speech for Senator Baume should be unemployed. It is a fiction of fact and fantasy.
—You will be soon, Senator!
—I do not need any help from those opposite. I listened to Senator Baume without any interjections; let me get to the main points I want to make.
—Tell us why this has happened.

—I am not responding to interjections. I will put this into perspective. As I have said on a dozen occasions, there has been a deep recession in Australia with consequent severe unemployment problems. This is a very serious and tragic problem. It is not just an Australian problem; it is exactly the same in the United Kingdom and Canada—there is more than 10 per cent unemployment in both countries. There is a very severe problem in the United States where they have none of the sorts of social safety nets that we have in Australia to try to alleviate some of this problem.
—You engineered this.

—Will you shut up, Rumpole! Senator Kemp really is a gabbler if ever there was one. He should be called Hedda Gabler. He cannot stop. Of course this is a serious problem. The Opposition's response to a serious problem is to say two things: `This Government is terrible and we have the solution to these problems. Therefore, we should be on the other side of the House'. That is what Senator Baume's speech was all about. He gave himself away by talking about Fightback.

PARA.TAB: I will refer to Fightback. In responding to this problem, I want those opposite to understand that there are a number of things that the Government will not do. The Government will not introduce a 15 per cent tax on every item of food and clothing that unemployed people in this country buy; we will not put long term unemployed people into the gutter after nine months like the Opposition plans to do; we will not adopt the New Zealand scheme that the Opposition is so in love with because that scheme means that young people who do not accept a wage less than the appropriate unemployment benefit can be barred from benefits for six months; we will not introduce poverty wages; and we will not introduce a tax scale which tremendously favours the rich as against the relatively poor taxpayers. The Government is committed to addressing the youth unemployment issue, but let me talk a little bit about the issue first.

Senator Baume went on about the figures. Unpalatable as it may be to him, as a very conservative man, seven out of 10 young Australians in the 15- to 19-year-old age group are either in education or employed. When this Government came to office, it was nothing like that figure. More young Australians are staying on in school than ever before. That is because with our education retention rates we seek to emulate the performance of countries like Japan and the United States. We have to do that if we are to be a successful economy which provides good, longer term employment in the future; that is, we have to have a better trained, better skilled work force than we have ever had before.

The point is that when talking about this problem one has to begin to try to understand it. It is no good throwing around figures as if juggling balls in the air. The fact is, as Senator Baume well knows, that there is a high percentage—31 per cent; in some States 35 per cent or so—of young people in the 15 to 19 age group who are unemployed and looking for jobs; that is, about a third of them perhaps. But, still, more than two-thirds of young people in Australia who want to work have work. Senator Baume makes these sorts of glib references to underemployed people—underemployed people in education institutions. It is an insult to those people and an insult to the education systems which are supporting them to say that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is false. I did not say that.
—He did say that. He will say anything in this place, as we have seen this week.
—I did not. Don't tell lies.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! Senator Baume, I ask you to withdraw that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw. Try to tell the truth, Minister.
—We are trying to understand the problems a little, and I do not appreciate interjections of that kind at the same time.
—I do not appreciate nonsense in your speech. You deliberately distort what I said.
—Senator Baume had better go outside and say a few of the things he has been saying this week and see how he gets on.
—I have done so.

—He should see how he gets on—and just wait a while. If we look at the impact that the fundamental restructuring of the labour market has on job opportunities for young people, we just have to face up to the fact that job opportunities that used to be available as entry level positions are now disappearing. That is because the nature of the work force is changing; the nature of the skills required is changing. It is due to organisational change and the introduction of new technologies that these jobs are diminishing.

PARA.TAB: These changes are common to all industrialised nations. They cannot be turned back. Any country that wants to face up to them has to have better education standards and skills training than that offered by the National-Country Party in its view of the world. The challenge is to develop the means by which young people can gain the skills they need for a restructured workplace. A competitive economy needs highly skilled people. There has never been a group of school leavers in Australia with higher levels of formal education than the group now entering the labour market.

The cry immediately comes back—and I appreciate this: where are the jobs for these skilled people? Of course, the jobs are not there for nearly one-third of those who are looking for them in an economy suffering from a recession and in which the restructuring process in industry is slowly taking place. But they will be there, and more of them will be there as we get out of the recession.

I have been here long enough to remember this Government's difficulties in getting out of the recession created by honourable senators opposite in 1982 and 1983—a cyclical recession in the Australian economy such as we largely have now. I have been here long enough, as I say, to look at the pattern of getting out of recession and at what happened in those years.

The same thing will happen again; as there is growth in the Australian economy, as people start to buy more goods and services and as exports continue on their merry way as they are now—better than ever before in the history of job intensive industries in this country—there will be an improvement in the job situation both generally and for young people. We cannot, as a matter of sensible government policy, walk away from the issue.

I want to mention one or two things which have happened. I referred to the safety net that we have in Australia which does not catch everybody—there are tragedies associated with youth unemployment. Part of that problem was addressed in the February government statement in terms of significant increases in the number of apprentice places and the provision of a further 10,000 pre-vocational training places for young people. A number of other matters were addressed in that February statement which try to alleviate this problem. We will not alleviate the problem by just putting people on the dole—or, as the Opposition would do, throwing them off the dole—but by trying to get them into productive activities in terms of training of one kind or another.

The Government is considering a number of other matters at present. We are not evading the problem, as Senator Baume likes to allege. It is an enormous problem for us as a government; more importantly, it is a huge problem for this society.

Many participants can contribute to a solution. In the next month or so, the participants who have been asked to help with providing solutions on the ground will be meeting with the Government to consider a number of matters relating to entry level training and so on. The Government is looking to reform entry level training and is looking closely at the Carmichael report, which is essentially about vocational education in Australia.

We have had enormous changes in tertiary education in this country in the last decade. There have also been enormous changes in the participation rates in secondary school education. Huge changes are evidenced by the fact that we now have 50 per cent more university places than we did in 1983. Those are huge changes.

The one area which has been significantly neglected—and I am not making any political point about this—is the TAFE system, which has been in the province of State governments. The present Government is trying to grasp that nettle and say, `We will make funding arrangements for the TAFE sector on the condition that many of these arrangements are reformed'. There is enormous room for improvement in the vocational training sector provided by TAFE. I am not blaming State governments for its failures; I am just saying that it is an issue which has not been properly addressed until now because it has been very much in the hands of State governments and there are a variety of reasons why they have not addressed it.

TAFE is an enormously important sector when looking at the job patterns of the future and the obvious fact that skills will change rapidly and people will be training and retraining throughout their working lives. The importance of that system to that sort of process is immense.

I said earlier that it is not just Australia that has these problems. We are fortunate in Australia in one area. Over the years, until Fightback came along—and I am not making any party political point about this—there has almost been a bipartisan approach in Australia to the respected social norm of providing social solutions, as far as possible, through the welfare and training systems to deal with problems of this kind which emerge in cyclical recessions and so on.

The United Kingdom and Canada have the same problems. I suppose that they are agonising over them in the same way as we are. In the United States, where the philosophy is different, it seems to me that there is not so much agony, except as it is reflected in a variety of urban problems and so on.

In Japan there is not such a problem, and there never has been because Japanese industry has always been very forward looking. Part of the ethos of Japanese industry is to maintain a corporate safety net, as distinct from a government safety net, to fit the times and situations involving change of employment. So Japanese corporations, with one notable exception recently, do not throw their employees into the government safety net in times of recession in a traditional business. They move their business into new areas, new activities; they are very flexible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ship them out to Australia as tour guides.

—That is an inept sort of solution. I do not think they would be as silly as that. I am talking about a population of 130 million or 140 million people. I find Senator O'Chee's solution to the problem mind-bogglingly inept. Japanese industry is very flexible. In addition to its role of returning corporate profits to its shareholders, it plays a social role in regard to its employees. We do not have a society like that. One day I hope we will. We have to understand the problem as being one of a changing pattern of employment due to restructuring and so on which is taking place in industry; and changing circumstances, profoundly sad circumstances, resulting from the recession.

PARA.TAB: We have had a lot of discussion about this issue in the past week. Everybody has been saying that we ought to debate youth unemployment. None of us should fool ourselves about this issue. It is all very well for politicians to come in here and debate this matter and shout slogans and comments at one another but every one of us knows that there is no solution in this place which can be implemented as a matter of urgency to deal with this tragic problem. There is no solution in this place; we are all talk up here. A little while ago, the President ruled out of order an interjection which described somebody in this place as a hypocrite. I respect the President's ruling—there are no hypocrites up here, none at all.

Senator Baume says that there are two issues involved: firstly, the Government has failed and, secondly, the Opposition has a solution. The Opposition's solution has Dr Hewson talking about creating two million jobs by the year 2000. There is not one piece of evidence in the whole Fightback! document that those opposite can do that. All they can say with certainty about the Fightback! document is that, if they came to power tomorrow, unemployment benefits would be changed; there would be a 15 per cent tax on food and clothing—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell the whole story!

—I am quite prepared to tell the whole story. Today, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer)—the Leader of Senator O'Chee's Party—is trying to screw up the courage of his national conference to stick with Fightback because many of the people in the National Party know that they do not have to be bullied by the Liberals down here—
—Don't you worry about that.

—Senator O'Chee, a well paid politician, will go to the National Party conference and stand them up. He has a job but there are plenty of people in the National Party who do not. That is why they are concerned about the Fightback proposals—they know they will do nothing for the unemployed.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators come in here day after day saying, `Let's debate this issue'. And what was the contribution from the leading Liberal Party spokesman?—A waffly suggestion that the Liberals ought to be in government because they will do something about these issues. Senator Lewis keeps interjecting. Every time anybody on the Government side says anything about the unemployment issue, he says, `Tell that to the unemployed'. I do not know whether he talks to them too much, but what does he tell the unemployed?—`I belong to this brilliant Party, led by Dr Hewson and his acolyte in the Senate, Senator Baume. If we get into office all these things are going to be fixed. Just sit there, brother, in the dole queue and we are going to fix all these things'. That is the level of debate which goes on here.

In the next month or so, the Government will be drawing together a whole range of parties in this community that are equally concerned about this issue, and we will try to work at the question of amelioration of the present problem. In the meantime, there will be further growth in the Australian economy which, in itself, will ameliorate this problem. I welcome the fact that the Opposition, after having talked about this issue for so long, has finally put forward for debate a matter of public importance on it, but let us just consider it as a matter of public importance. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today on behalf of the Australian Democrats to support this very important matter of public importance debate about youth unemployment. Given that we have been debating this issue now for some 40 minutes, I think it is worth repeating to the Senate exactly what it is we are debating. The terms of the MPI are:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's refusal to acknowledge the extent of Australia's youth unemployment disaster which the Prime Minister is now trying to disguise, and its failure to take effective action to fix it.

I acknowledge Senator Button's earlier contribution that there are no easy answers to this problem. Nobody has the magic wand that will make this problem go away tomorrow. Much of the unemployment we are seeing in the Australian economy is structural. As I said this morning, many of the low-skilled and unskilled jobs that young people once did on leaving school at the age of 15 or 16 simply do not exist any more for them. So it is absolutely critical, in order for young people nowadays to take their part in the workplace, that training be given an absolutely high priority by this Government and to ensure that we are not simply leaving thousands and thousands of young people without hope and without jobs through lack of training opportunities.

PARA.TAB: However, the statement on unemployment yesterday by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is, in our belief, simply face-saving rhetoric and an attempt on the part of the Government to paper over what is a very serious problem. It does not matter if unemployment is 10 per cent or 34 per cent amongst young people. The figures show that thousands of young people and thousands of older people are suffering. It is ridiculous and the height of arrogance for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to suggest that the ABS figures are incorrect and not a true reflection of what is happening in society.

Yesterday in the Senate I cited the latest OECD quarterly labour force statistics which compare Australia with our international trading partners. I was astonished, when I asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, whether he had seen these figures, to find that he had not. He was unable to provide any explanation to this Parliament as to why Australia is almost at the very top of this list.

I will read out some of these figures because I think it is very instructive for honourable senators to hear them. At the top of the list, with the highest level of unemployment for young people between the ages of 14 and 24 years, is Italy, at 49.6 per cent. The next country is Portugal, with 41.5 per cent of its young people out of work. The third highest country is Switzerland—surprisingly—with 40.6 per cent of its young people out of work. However, Switzerland's figures are slightly different, as they have been calculated on the basis of the 15- to 30-year-old age group, which is slightly different from the Australian figures.

Australia is next on the list with 38.8 per cent of its work force between the ages of 15 and 24 out of work. Those were figures, I would point out, from the last quarter of 1991, that is, six months ago. I am told that the next set of OECD labour market figures will be coming out in a month's time. I spoke to the Minister yesterday and expressed my surprise that he had not seen these figures. He assured me that he would make sure that these labour market figures were put on the top of his reading in his office. I certainly hope that he has an opportunity to look at those figures when they come out next month because I am willing to bet that those figures will in fact have worsened over the last six months. They will not have improved and we are going to see a very much greater level of youth unemployment compared with our OECD trading partners.

The costs of youth unemployment cannot be quantified. Apart from the loss of skills and talent, the impact on self-esteem and dignity is devastating not only for young people but also for everyone else out of work. I am sure that every senator in this place knows of someone who is out of work at the moment, someone who is really suffering. I know that, in my own family, there are people very close to me who have been out of work for some time. I have a real appreciation and understanding of the depression that that causes, of the difficulty that that places families in and of the kinds of stresses that that places on relationships. This is happening right around Australia and it is critical that the Government and the Opposition recognise this and, likewise, recognise that there are no easy solutions to the problem. The Democrats recognise that as well.

The Smith Family released statistics only a couple of weeks ago. They are the results of a survey which indicated that an overwhelming 90 per cent of unemployed people are sacrificing some meals and not buying clothes so that they can survive in the recession. That is an astonishing statistic. More than 50 per cent of people are selling their personal belongings to survive. So we are creating, in effect, almost a permanent underclass of people who are simply having to give up everything in order to live, in order to feed their families and in order to survive in these tough economic times.

I have already mentioned the denial of training and education opportunities for young people. We have seen this year the incredible statistics of 100,000 students missing out on places at TAFE and 50,000 students missing out on places at universities. While this is of course a product of the recession and a product of the very high retention rates that have occurred over the last few years—I acknowledge the Government's contribution in that respect and also that of State governments which have made every effort to keep young people at school longer—it is the height of hypocrisy for the Government to stand up here and baldly say that it is okay for those students to not gain places. It is not good enough for the Government to simply say that the university sector has reached its optimum level and therefore should not be allowed to grow any further. The fact is that there are young people who want those places.

The Government needs to recognise that funding for higher education has actually declined as a percentage of gross domestic product over the last three years. In fact, only recently, the AVCC has come out demanding that the Government restore funding for higher education to 1983 levels as a percentage of gross domestic product. I think that is a critical move that the Government must make. It must not simply throw the odd handout at education every time it wants to bring down an economic statement of some kind and expect that that will deal with the problem, placate parents whose children cannot find a job and placate the higher education sector which is plagued with under-resourcing, overcrowding and cuts to staff.

The higher education sector is in absolutely desperate straits at the moment. Just go to the University of Sydney and see how packed those lectures are. Kids cannot even get in to them or they have to sit on the stairs and stand around the walls and take notes. That is overcrowding. Kids are going to tutorials and finding that there are 30 people in the same tutorial; that they cannot actually get the kind of personal teaching they were once entitled to. There is a really very desperate situation in our higher education institutions.

Libraries are having to cut their buying because their budgets are being slashed. That, of course, will have a long term impact on postgraduate research, on the quality of our undergraduate degrees and on the quality of resources offered by universities.

The TAFE sector is very high on the Government agenda. I congratulate the Government for finally, after so long, seeing the need to inject a measure of national planning into what has previously been a very uncoordinated area of education policy. The Government is to be congratulated for that. But I plead with the Government, instead of simply bullying the States around the head into accepting its offer to assume responsibility for TAFE funding, to do it in a cooperative way. It should be done with the cooperation and consultation of the States, not by simply kicking them around the head and making stupid announcements such as that made recently by the Prime Minister on the Sunday program that he would set up a separate system of vocational training. That is just lunacy. It is ridiculous. There is no way that that could possibly be considered as fiscally responsible in this current climate.

The Government must cooperate with the States. It must address the real issues of a national curriculum; it must address the issue of credit transfer; and it must address the issue of resourcing. We recognise that the Government has set aside $720m in the One Nation statement for the growth in the TAFE sector and, of course, it is to be congratulated for that. But it is time that the planning in this area was cooperative and not done with bully-boy tactics.

The Prime Minister has made lofty statements about a youth job summit, and again we welcome that. It is high time that those groups of people in the Australian community who are affected and those involved in planning and delivering social welfare services were actually consulted as to what kinds of measures should be taken to deal with this problem. However, it is our concern that this summit will simply become a giant talkfest for government, for bureaucrats and for peak lobby groups, and that the real voice of youth will simply be eliminated by the whole bureaucracy of the great affair. If the Government wants to find out what is really happening amongst young people and what issues are of concern to young people, it needs to make sure that it brings young people to that table—and not just articulate opinion leaders amongst youth. The Government needs to find out what is happening in the western suburbs of Sydney, where some suburbs have unemployment rates among young people of 44 per cent. The Government needs to find and talk to those young people who are in desperate straits, not the opinion leaders and the articulate young people who are far removed from the problems of those who are without a job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not Young Labor, either!
—That is perfectly right—and not Young Liberals. It has to be a cross-section of young people from across Australia.
—Not young Democrats either!

—I am sure there will be plenty of young Democrats who will be very happy to come. The legacy of unemployment is not pleasant. It affects people's whole lives, their families and their livelihood. However, we have heard the Opposition today saying that Fightback is the universal panacea for Australia's unemployment woes. Most Australians would be very sceptical of that claim and are yet to be convinced of the merits of Fightback. I would like the Opposition to explain to the Australian people and to the thousands and thousands of people currently unemployed, especially the growing numbers who have been out of work for more than 12 months, how it will implement its policy of cutting the dole after nine months. This seems to be an absolutely ridiculous policy. It has been said as baldly as that—that the dole will be cut after nine months. The Opposition needs to explain to the Australian people how it expects unemployed young people and older people to survive in that kind of climate.

PARA.TAB: The Government is fiddling the figures and the Opposition offers no solutions for the long term unemployed. The Prime Minister's statement on youth unemployment is shameful. He has tried to fiddle the figures yet again, and it is an insult to the Australian community for him to suggest—with 300 people in Adelaide queuing up for 12 casual positions with the Great Australian Ice Creamery—that we have less than 10 per cent unemployment amongst young people. That seems to be an absolutely ludicrous proposition and one that is completely unsustainable if the Prime Minister took the time to actually get out into the streets and find out what is happening.

The Australian Medical Association's Vice-President, Dr Brendan Nelson, recently released a study on the health of unemployed people. I congratulate the AMA for its recent conference into the health effects of unemployment—a very timely and important conference. He said that unemployment is a serious threat to health and showed that unemployed people were prone to health problems: 85 per cent of unemployed women were in poor or fair health and 20 per cent of jobless men are more likely to die than those in employment. That is a staggering statistic and is unlikely to go away with the current high levels of unemployment in this country.

The Prime Minister must stop misleading the Australian people by fiddling the figures and start talking in a real and honest way to the people of Australia to ensure that their voices are heard and not simply trying to make people believe the unbelievable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to start by saying that I thought Senator Sowada was above purveying the untruths of the other side in saying that our policy is that unemployment benefits would stop after nine months. I ask her to read our policy before she gets up again to give the same old story as Senator Button and Senator Cook.

PARA.TAB: Today in Question Time Senator Button said that the people on this side of the chamber thrived on bad news. I found that offensive and unacceptable. I do not thrive on bad news. In fact, I do not thrive and am not joyed that the youth jobless rate in my State has more than tripled in the last two years. It has tripled in two years in Senator Evans's State and mine. I do not know about his kids, but a lot of kids in Victoria do not have jobs. He can smile and smirk, but three times the number of young people cannot get jobs now compared with two years ago.

The anti-job cocktail of Keating and Kirner has taken the Victorian rate from the lowest in the country two years ago to the highest. That is why I am on my feet today. It has gone from the lowest in Australia to the highest. In April this year Mr Baldwin went around the country peddling the claim that youth unemployment was 8.8 per cent. SPEECH.PARA: . . . Senator Kay Patterson. . . put out a press statement which said that one in two young Victorians is unemployed. This has to be rightfully seen as an outrageous and deceptive statement by Senator Patterson.

I wish to set the record straight. The number of unemployed teenagers seeking full time work represents 9.9 per cent of the teenage population, not 34 per cent as claimed by the Opposition.

Those opposite cannot have it both ways. The Labor Party, and Senator Button, Senator Cook and Senator Ray in particular, love to go back to the old days of 1985 and 1983. They regurgitate the figures. I take them back to 16 October 1985 when Senator Cook said:

The real priority of this Government is youth and youth programs. . . It is a program that gives real hope and a real future to the young people of Australia. It is assigned the highest priority by the Government. . . It is a program aimed at giving careers, futures and hope to the young people of Australia.

Hope? What hope, when the number of young unemployed Victorians has tripled in the past two years? What does Senator Cook say? This indicates that, even when unemployment falls to 5 per cent, youth unemployment is still likely to be well over 10 per cent.

PARA.TAB: In 1985, because it suited his argument, Senator Cook said that youth unemployment was 26.1 per cent while overall unemployment was 8.3 per cent; that is, youth unemployment was three times higher. Now, because it suits his argument, Senator Cook says that youth unemployment—which we are saying is 34.1 per cent; in his fiddled figures it is 9.4 per cent—is less than the overall unemployment rate of 10.6 per cent. I do not care whether he is a mathematician or not; Senator Cook cannot have 26.1 per cent to 8.3 per cent being three times greater than 34.1 per cent to 10.6 per cent. It just does not add up. Senator Cook is quite happy to use that 1985 figure, but he will not use it now because he wants to hide the figure for the unemployment rate of young Australians. He wants to hide the unemployment figure. It does not add up. It makes a farce of a statement he made on April Fool's Day this year—a very appropriate day for Senator Cook to get up and say:

SPEECH.PARA: What cannot be said of us is that we have ever tried to hide the fact. We have always been honest about the level of unemployment in this country and what needs to be done about it.
Well, boo hoo to Senator Cook; boo hoo to him! April Fool's Day was the perfect day for him to make that sort of a statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Grow up.

—I say to Senator Cook—I mean Senator Evans, or whatever his name is; I confused Senator Evans once before with Senator Cook, and one is as bad as the other—thank heavens I am grown up. When Senator Evans and I were growing up in the baby boom—I put him in the same category as I am—we had every opportunity in the world. We will leave to the next generation a worse standard of living than we inherited. That is the only generation that will experience that. That is the legacy that the parents born in the baby boom—and this Government, in particular—will leave to our children.

PARA.TAB: In the State with the worst level of youth unemployment—Victoria—we find that in May 1992 youth unemployment was 46.1 per cent, three times the February 1990 figure of 14.3 per cent. In May 1992, 37,300 young people were looking for full time work, double the February 1990 number of 18,600. That is only part of the story. Senator Baume raised some of these issues. We have to look at the number of unemployed youth including those who because of the economic conditions are working less than 35 hours a week and people in part time work who want to work more hours. In April 1992 that figure for Australia was 90,600 and for Victoria it was 22,900.

We also have to look at youth who are marginally attached to the labour force; that is, those people who are actively looking for work but who do not meet the criteria to be included in the labour force—people who want to work, who are not actively looking for work but who would be available for work within four weeks if offered a job. In September 1991—these are the latest figures—168,400 young people, 153 per cent of the full time youth unemployment figure, were marginally attached. That is almost the same number as that for unemployed youth, of 176,600.

I said that in Victoria the number of youth looking for full time work equalled 37,300. The total number of unemployed youth in Victoria is 45,800. I do not have the figures for marginally attached youth in Victoria, but if we apply the 153 per cent increase for Australia to those who are marginally attached in Victoria, which is an estimated 91,000 or 2 1/2 times the full time youth unemployment rate and two times the total unemployment rate, if we really want the full picture, we have to add on the 22,900 underemployed. That gives a total of 114,000 young people in Victoria who want to work.

If we use the same process for Australia—taking into account those two additional groups—there are 420,000 to 425,000 young people who want to work. The percentage of 15- to 19-year-olds in the total population is 1.4 million. So the 420,000 people who want to work constitute 30 per cent of the total youth population. That is one in three young Australians. The real unemployment rate is the same as the official figure of 34 per cent. Senator Cook, Mr Baldwin and Mr Keating can fiddle the figures all they like, but one in three young Australians cannot get a job; those who want to work cannot get work.

What is the cost of youth unemployment? Mr Burdekin tells us that the cost is increased youth homelessness. Mr Glare, the chief police officer in Victoria, told us yesterday that the cost is rising crime. What else did we hear in the press a couple of days ago? We heard that the cost is increased youth suicide, especially amongst young males and, in particular, young males in the country. On a Pru Goward program some months ago we were told that 90 per cent of young males who suicided in the country in a particular period were unemployed. The person who carried out the study thought that that was one of the major factors. What else do we have? We have poor health, psychological problems of depression and drug and alcohol abuse. It is a legacy of disasters for young people.

Mr Keating has presided over a number of records. In his youth—he grew up in the generation that I was part of—the world was his oyster. He was in a rock band. I do not know whether it made records, but he got good practice if it did because he is now the Australian record holder. Mr Keating has presided over record unemployment, record bankruptcies, record tax grabs, record child poverty—remember, no child was going to live in poverty—record interest rates, record foreign debt, record crime statistics, record hospital queues, record farm failures, record family break-ups and divorces, and now, added to his list of records, record youth unemployment. That is what we have got from Mr Keating. Mr Keating now has a platinum record for youth unemployment. At the next election the Australian public will give him a golden handshake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a matter of public importance on the subject of youth unemployment. What the Government has to say at the beginning is what we have been saying all along and will continue to say while the problem of unemployment generally and that of youth unemployment continues to be a serious problem in our community: we deplore it as an issue, we deplore it as a problem, and we sympathise and make common cause with those people who suffer because of it.

PARA.TAB: Our record as a political party and as a government has been to fight unemployment first. In the 1980s when we were up for election the Opposition's view was to fight unemployment and inflation simultaneously. Our position has always been to fight the level of unemployment.

Having said that, this matter of public importance comes down to three clear and simple things: what is the true position with regard to youth unemployment and unemployment generally; what can be done about it; and what are the comparative programs of the two major political parties in terms of who is going to do most about it?

In relation to the first issue—what is the true position?—we have, clearly for political self-interest purposes, obfuscation, competing statistics, manipulation of statistics and the presentation of statistical data in order to make the problem appear much worse than it really is. While I understand that that is the role of an opposition and it is a common thing for oppositions to do, nonetheless, if one is to have a logical program to deal with the problem, we have to be clear about what the problem is and how it is best described.

During the debate on this matter of public importance those opposite have said that the Government refuses to acknowledge the true level of youth unemployment. What we have refused to do, and what we will continue to refuse to do, is dishonestly misrepresent the level of youth unemployment in order to support the political argument that the Opposition wants to make. We will cleave to dispassionate, logical analysis to clarify what the case is.In simple terms, the case is this: as a component of the labour force, seven out of 10 young people between the ages of 15 and 19 years are being trained or are in educational institutions in one way or another; three are in the labour force; and two are working.

So when the Opposition and some misguided journalists allege that the level of youth unemployment in Australia is 34 per cent, and that one in three young people in this country are unemployed, that is a play on statistics which misrepresents the situation.The true figure is that, of the total youth population, one in three are not unemployed; 9.9 per cent are unemployed. While the Opposition will not recognise that fact and wants to go with the more dramatic figure, nonetheless, drama does not equal truth, and on this occasion drama equals misrepresentation.

The clear difference between the political parties in Australia has been that we have supported, and during our period of government have contributed more heavily to, education, training and open access to education and training than has the Opposition. The Opposition is talking about a reduced commitment to technical education and training; making access to university education the preserve of the wealthy; reducing the opportunities of equal access if one cannot afford the fees; and deregulating the labour market so that young people would become victims of the labour market and not be afforded the interests of equity, true compassion and concern.

In Australia we have a comparison between our vision and the Opposition's. Our vision is for an Australia which is highly skilled, highly trained and able to absorb international technology at a great rate to let us enjoy a competitive edge in world level skills. We want to turn our economy into a globally competitive economy based on high skills and, yes, high pay as well. That is why since 1983 we have committed ourselves to increase funding to universities in this country by increasing spending in real terms by 42 per cent. That is why since 1983 we have created in this country the equivalent of 17 new universities. That is why in the One Nation statement—a statement about regenerating and bringing the Australian economy back into economic growth—we have made a commitment to pouring an extra $720m into technical and further education in Australia to make training opportunities in technical, trade and work related skills more accessible for young Australians. Those are our commitments.

That is why we have a range of programs for unemployed people to have access to training—a range of programs which, compared with what the Opposition proposes through its consumption tax, sometimes called the Fightback package—supports people who are unemployed and gives them access to training. The Fightback package reduces access, limits training and kicks young people off the dole after they have been on it for nine months so that they can then fend for themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is bulldust and you know it.

—That is not bulldust; that is an accurate comparison—an uncomfortable one for Senator Campbell, but an accurate comparison. When we talk about the true position, the true position is not the one produced here by Senator Baume and others in a highly coloured political way. The true position is, nonetheless, worrying and concerning. The true position is that we have committed ourselves to a highly skilled, highly educated economy. We have put our money where our mouth is, and the opportunities are greater now for education and training than ever before in the history of this country and, given our continuance in office, will continue to be greater. The truth is that the Opposition's Fightback package—the tax everybody and benefit the rich package—reduces training opportunities and limits access to higher education to those who are wealthy. That is the true situation.

PARA.TAB: What can be done about it? Youth unemployment is serious—and we walk away not one whit from that problem—but it is by no means the most serious area of unemployment. Other categories of workers, particularly aged workers, are in a much more serious situation than that of youth, but for the purposes of this debate we are focusing on young people. What can be done about it is the key issue. What can be done is to develop the Australian economy; take it out of recession and into growth. Through economic growth, we can produce new and better careers, not just jobs. It is not just an issue of jobs. In a highly technological world, new and better careers are careers based on skills and training which can be adapted to meet new technology, as I have said.

The One Nation statement was about regenerating growth in the Australian economy. When we look across the range of economic indicators at the moment, what do we find? We find what we forecast—that there will be no sudden rebound of the economy; there will be slower growth. It will come at a more general level, but it will be solid. It will not go up in a straight line; it will go up in a flatter line, but it will be solid and real. It will be real because of the restructuring of the Australian economy we have undertaken, to turn it from an economy crouching defensively behind a high tariff barrier into an economy which is globally competitive. It will be a solid recovery.

Where are we in terms of that recovery? We are in the early stages of it. The signs in housing approvals, the first sign of economic revival, are strong. The signs in new motor vehicle registrations, an early indication of consumer confidence, are up. The number of vacancies advertised in the `Situations Vacant' pages are a sign of increasing job offerings, and all of the indexes that deal with job opportunities are lifting, which indicates that more jobs are becoming available. According to the accurate indications, we are in the early stages of an economic resurgence—an economic resurgence based on restructuring, which will mean that productivity will grow dramatically in the forthcoming months.

It is in the situation of early recovery, in which one of the key issues to fuel and strengthen that recovery is confidence of the business community, that those opposite, as the professional knockers in Australia, wish to damage the nature of the recovery by taking the political argument down to its meanest, narrowest and lowest denominator. As knockers, good news for the economy is bad news for their electoral prospects; they will never allow their electoral prospects to be damaged by economic growth, so why not have a go at knocking yet again and try to damage the essential ingredient of confidence?

It comes to a question of who is best equipped to deal with this matter. We have a range of programs which are geared to meeting the needs of unemployment and retraining people while they are unemployed. We think that in the circumstances this matter requires re-examination. That is why the Prime Minister has called for the youth meeting to be held next month—to re-examine whether we are right about all of the settings or whether we need to revisit some of them and tweak them up or improve them in various ways.

It will be an important meeting. It may well be that arising from it there is a fresher approach or we find that the settings are right but need a further commitment of funds or that the economic recovery is taking hold in a stronger way by then and that the settings are right and need to be left alone. But that is an important meeting and, in the interests of this MPI to the question of what is being done about it, that is one of the immediate things that is being done about it.

Let me in the few minutes that I have left return to the Fightback proposition because that is the Opposition's alternative agenda. As I said, the Opposition does not really care about training. This was admitted by Mr Howard himself, the shadow Minister in this area. On 7 May he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I want us to go back to a situation that used to exist when I left school, and that is, that if you wanted to get a job as a kid you could. And, we used to have a saying in Australia called the dead end job. That referred to somebody who got a job that didn't involve any kind of training, but you could get those in the 50s and 60s, you can't get them any more.

We are not interested in dead-end jobs—bicycle couriers around capital cities, lift attendants, kids working in fast food outlets with minimum skills. They are dead-end jobs. They are not the jobs of the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't put them down.
—I do not put them down, but I do not say that they are jobs with great prospects, and nor does Senator Campbell think they are.
—Courier drivers are a pretty special bunch of people.

—They are not jobs of high skill and they are not jobs to fit an economy to meet the challenges of the next century. Senator Campbell knows that and he is demeaning his own knowledge by pretending that he does not know that. We are not interested in dead-end jobs, but apparently Mr Howard is interested in dead-end jobs.

PARA.TAB: We will not, as the Fightback package proposes, scrap unemployment benefits for unemployed people after nine months. We will not abolish the Commonwealth Employment Service as the Fightback package will or abolish the Youth Access Centre as the Fightback package proposes. We will not downgrade technical and further education as the Fightback package will. We will not introduce university fees so that only the rich can gain admittance to university; nor are we going to abolish the student homeless allowance.

The Opposition has put down its Fightback package. I thought it was a courageous—nay, somewhat stupid—political act, but the Opposition has tacked its colours to the mast. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —For someone such as Senator Cook to say that we need more than talk, talk, talk and we need more than Fightback and policies, he has taken up 15 or so minutes giving us just talk. PARA.TAB: This argument is about the tactic that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Senator Cook have undertaken this week; that is, to all of a sudden say that youth unemployment is only one in 10 or 9.9 per cent and not as devastating as each and every one of us in this place and the people in the gallery here today know it is. We have seen from anecdotal evidence, from crime figures, from drug figures and from the devastation amongst young Australians that there is a real problem out there, and to say that youth unemployment is now 9.9 per cent is bulldust and just that.

If that is the case, then for the first time in Australia's history, and probably for the first time in the history of the free world, youth unemployment is indeed less than that of adult unemployment, and all of us know that is not true. We can talk about how many people are in training and in employment. It is probably a very good thing that there are more people being educated in Australia, but we need to see how they are being educated. Are they being trained for jobs that are there? Are they being trained for jobs that will improve their lot and the lot of the nation when they get out of it?

I refer to a report by the Graduate Careers Council of Australia released on Monday, 9 December 1991. It talks about the outlook for graduates and looks at the outlook for people with trade and apprenticeship skills in Australia. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The proportion of graduates seeking full-time employment would undoubtedly have been higher but for this rise in further study numbers. It would seem that some graduates decided to `shelter' from the difficult labour market, whilst strengthening their qualifications at the same time.

That may not be a bad thing to do. But let us not kid ourselves, as this Government wants to do, about the real level of youth unemployment; let us face the fact that whether the unemployment rate is 40 per cent, 30 per cent, 20 per cent or 50 per cent we have a really big problem. The problem will not be solved by having another summit, another talkfest—which the former Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, made very popular a few years ago. Let us just face the problem.

PARA.TAB: Australia needs to create jobs. We can do that only by reforming our transport sector, our telecommunications sector, our tax system and our industrial relations system. Reform, reform, reform is the answer, not talk, talk, talk as we have had from Government senators. What we are saying here is irrelevant to the young kids who will sleep in the cold tonight, who will be shooting up amphetamines and drugs, who will be knocking off cars and radios and who will be leaving home and breaking marriages. They need action. The problem will not be solved overnight; it will take years and years to fix. We will not fix the problem by kidding ourselves about the real rate of unemployment. That is what the Prime Minister and Senator Cook have tried to do this week. The point that the Opposition makes, if it cannot make any other point in this place today, is that that will not solve the problem. Let us face up to it; let us do something about it; let us not put our head in the sand.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! Before calling Senator Giles I acknowledge that—besides Senator Campbell—Senator Giles and Senator Harradine are listed for the debate and we must conclude at 3.45 p.m. I thank Senator Campbell for restricting himself. I call Senator Giles.

TALK.START.PARA: —I add my thanks to Senator Campbell for his courtesy and I will extend the same courtesy to Senator Harradine. In a time of recession not only in Australia but worldwide, in a time of rapid and drastic changes to the structure of the work force, plus an educational culture which has resulted in generations of neglect of post-secondary education in Australia, it is inevitable that it all adds up to a high percentage of young people in neither employment nor education or training. The percentage does matter despite what Senator Sowada believes. I am rather disappointed that she has apparently joined the statistics illiterates opposite. The demoralisation factor in being told that 30-plus per cent of one's age group is unemployed is obviously three times as great as being convinced, as these young people should be because it is accurate, that only one in 10 of that particular cohort is not in the work force and wants to be, and also is not involved in education or training.

PARA.TAB: The question should be: why are these young people not being given the advantage of education, training or work experience? The culture is changing, I suggest. Under this Government, school retention rates have dramatically increased. In 1984, only 48 per cent of young women were in the education system and now 70 per cent are; 42 per cent of young males were in the education system in 1984 and now 58 per cent are.

I know the argument which says that because there are no jobs these young people stay at school as the only viable alternative and that they would much rather be working. There are some interesting statistics that might back up the notion that young people are making sensible choices about their futures. Of those who completed 12 years of education in the late 1980s, only 3.9 per cent were unemployed; of those who did not complete 12 years of education, 13.8 per cent were unemployed.

Young people are perfectly well aware of the fact that by staying on to complete at least 12 years of education they have a much better opportunity of being employed and of enhancing the economic position of the country generally with a much better educated work force. I believe that this is the way we are headed; this is the way we should go. The opportunities for young people are increasing all the time within the education and training systems.

At this stage, 95,000 young women and 70,000 young men are studying basic employment skills in the TAFE system. Achievements over this period to help women and persuade them to stay in the system have been quite dramatic. Memories of the depression and so forth I do not think are particularly useful. The way in which statistics were collected in those days differed significantly from the way in which they are collected now. One should also beware of international comparisons. Those which come from the OECD are invariably qualified one way or another. Switzerland is a classic example. Only citizens are allowed to work in Switzerland—and one gets the distinct impression that many of its other residents are simply not counted.

However, the reference to the summit is extremely relevant to this debate. I would like to assure people who are concerned about it that the real voice of youth in Australia certainly will be heard at the summit, not just those voices of the opinion leaders, whose opinions are extremely important if they are genuinely reflective of the way in which young people think—and I have no reason to believe that that would not be the case.

But every effort will be made to ensure that out of this summit comes a plan which will take us perhaps more rapidly towards the point where we have not only a growing economy and a low inflation rate which will make growth much more timely, but also a work force which is trained and has the capacity for retraining, too, for a very different industrial and employment environment from the one which was faced by their mothers, grandmothers or even their older sisters. I will cede what remains of my time to Senator Harradine.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put a matter on the record in the adjournment debate because of a near tragedy that occurred yesterday in Tasmania. I attempted today to ask a question of Senator Collins in his capacity as the Minister for Transport and Communications but unfortunately, because of the long answers from Ministers and whatever, I could not.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday at about 6.40 a.m. a steel fishing boat called the Gail-Jenette II had the misfortune of coming into contact with a floating stump. Unfortunately, it was sunk. It was 15 miles off the Friendly Beaches on the east coast of Tasmania. Because of our new system of emergency communications, it was just pure luck that a fishing boat managed to pick up its distress calls and a tragedy was averted.

I refer the Senate to comments I made in this place in 1990 when it was made known that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority was going to take over and change the system of radio communications around Australia and, in particular, disband Hobart Radio, which provided a very efficient service for fishermen and pleasure craft owners around Tasmania. You would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, that Tasmania has what are regarded as some of the most treacherous oceans in the world. Waves measured on the west coast of Tasmania have been as high as any ever recorded; and, as we all know, Bass Strait is regarded as one of the most dangerous stretches of ocean in the world.

One could understand that, when the Government decided to close down Hobart Radio in 1990, it was greeted with a lot of scepticism by fishing boat and recreational boat owners. As I said, I raised this matter earlier, but, in typical bureaucratic fashion, both the Government and the Department of Transport and Communications assured all those who cried foul at this move that there was nothing to worry about and that the lives of those in ships around the Tasmanian coast would not be put at risk by this cost saving measure.
I will read from a media release that was put out by AMSA on 1 February this year:

SPEECH.PARA: The introduction of a new sophisticated marine radio system provided Australia with one of the best distress communication networks in the world, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority said today.
Senator Collins was here on many occasions when I raised this question in 1990, and the Hobart Mercury ran an editorial raising the concerns of Tasmanian fishermen.

PARA.TAB: The upshot of it is that yesterday at 6.40 a.m. when this near tragedy occurred, the fishermen in question tried unsuccessfully on 2, 4, 6 and 8 megahertz, which are the radio channels that this new system operates under, but could not raise Melbourne. They then turned to the local fishing boat channels, 4620 and 4535, but all to no avail. Then they called the emergency channel, channel 28, on their other radio, but they still had no reply. They tried all these other frequencies, including the emergency 2182 frequency on the first radio, but there was still no reply.

In the end, it was just by pure chance that Tim Bailey, a fishermen from Bicheno, happened to turn on his radio to call his son who works on the Southern Voyager, a trawler out of Hobart. He thought he would call his son and have a word with him. He turned the radio on and heard, `Mayday, mayday'. He found out that these people were in trouble. He got their co-ordinates and realised that his boat was very close by. They decided that they would send up a flare. He motored over to them. It was not all that far. Within two minutes of his arriving, the boat had gone down. It was just pure luck that he happened to turn his radio on that morning.

He was told by the fishermen in question—and I found this out this afternoon by ringing the insurance assessor in Hobart—that the radio equipment on that modern steel hulled boat was the latest SSB equipment which is required under this new system. It was called a Barrett 250, and made in Western Australia. There should not have been any problem in pumping out a strong enough signal for Melbourne to pick up, or even the other alternative which is Sydney. They tried and tried.

This is not the first time this has happened. There was another occurrence down at Port Davey when a young fisherman unfortunately took off one of his fingers whilst pulling in craypots. All the boats in the area—about five of them, including the Katrina Marie—tried to get assistance to get a helicopter into Port Davy to get him out. It was just pure luck that a fishing vessel in Bass Strait managed to pick up the call for assistance and immediately relayed the call to Melbourne. A funny thing happened in that Melbourne contacted the Katrina Marie straight away. One wonders how Melbourne could contact a boat down there yet the fishermen could not pick up Melbourne.

I am not saying that it is negligence on the part of the operators in Melbourne. From speaking to fishermen today, I believe that they are very pleased with the operators in Melbourne. The matter was raised with the Minister when it was decided to abandon Hobart Radio that, because there are areas in Tasmania where the reception is not good, this new system would not be good enough. The Government was warned repeatedly by all those people involved, including the marine police, yet it went ahead and closed down the translators on Bruny Island which did provide, through Melbourne, a much better system. That has gone now and we have these situations which are unacceptable.

The fishermen that I know in Tasmania asked me to put this matter forward today and I thought it was an opportune time to do so, although I know that people want to catch planes to go home. I do not think we should let this matter rest. The loss of this vessel and the circumstances surrounding the rescue once again have raised the question of whether this Government places greater importance on saving a few dollars than on the lives of boat users around the Tasmanian coast.

We know that fishermen are often at sea for weeks at a time, and many of them do not inform their colleagues of where they are going because they are frightened that their colleagues might find out where they are fishing. As I said earlier, if it had not been for that bit of luck—the chance occurrence of the fisherman Tim Bailey turning on his radio—it may have been several weeks before the authorities would have even known where these fishermen were. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), who is at the table, can tap his watch but I intend to put this on the record.
I hope that the staff in Senator Collins's office are listening. I raised this matter with the Department of Transport and Communications and received a letter which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department is aware that mariners, and particularly those in certain localised areas, have grown up with a system of local radio communications that they know and trust, and which have provided an excellent service.
The letter continued:
Also, recognise that it is a major step to change to a new system in which they do not yet have the same confidence. . .

I can tell the Senate that they do not have confidence in this system. I ask the Government to again look at re-opening Hobart Radio so that we do not end up in a situation where we have a tragedy as has happened in the past. Tasmania is unfortunately well known for tragedies at sea. We remember the Blythe Star; we remember the Japanese fishing boat that was sunk; and we remember plenty of other fishermen. Thank you for listening, Mr Acting Deputy President. I just hope that the Minister's staff are listening and that they take note of what I have had to say today.
